reviewText:
Genre - Fantasy Dungeon Management/RTS

I played the original 'Dungeon Keeper' and add on pack to the end back in the day, enjoying them greatly. I bought a game called 'Dungeons' on Steam a few years ago and was dissappointed. It played more like 'the Sims - Dungeon Keeper'.

When I saw this game was out and saw a high proportion of negative reviews I had low expectations. However, with a 10% discount and free DLC and some positive reviews I gave them my money and booted it up, with fingers crossed. Oh I am so glad I did!

This is the Dungeon Keeper clone we have been waiting for. It stays true to the original game whilst adding enough new stuff to keep it fresh. Also this is just an early build with active work taking place, but it still plays great. The game mechanics work here and I didn't realise how important the RTS element was, making the game more competitive and challenging. True you don't really design a dungeon for adventurers to explore (Sword Coast: Legends will allow you to do this I am sure).

You are basically an evil master who encourages minions and sets the hordes against your foes, sometimes stubborn Dwarves and other times your similar skilled brethren. The game plays at a fast enough pace so you don't get bored. I have already gone back to previous campaign missions to chase missing achievements as they are all so much fun. I still have the final two campaign levels to go, and am looking forward to my free DLC

If you are a retro gamer who enjoyed Dungeon Keeper you should like this game; if you are into Fantasy and RTS games you will enjoy this game and if you are both you will LOVE this game!
voteText: 22 of 36 people (61%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Really fun! I didn't really play the original dungeon keeper games, I think I was too young to appreciate them, but I really enjoy this a lot! It does indeed seem like it should still be early access, there are plenty of bugs and the tooltips don't really explain what everything does.

The campaign does slowly introduce you to new features and mechanics, but if you stop playing for a while, then go back to it and forget, you are left to Google how everything works because not every thing is intuitive and there's nothing to help you in game.

This is more of a 'god' type RTS (like Black & White) where you don't have to micromanage every little thing your units do. Just provide them with what they need, give them basic orders from time to time and they are kind of self sustaining. My kind of RTS! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game brings me back to Dungeon Keeper. Ah, how I loved those games. I was so excited to see that War for the Overlord is a game using not only the same mechanics, but even Richard Ridings, who's voice is like liquid sex evil.

There are a few things I disllike, but it's based in on the fact that the game is still in Beta. There's not really a storyline developed for play yet. There's no multiplayer (Comming Soon™). The few maps that you cna play are really limited in resources.

I know these things will get developed and ironed out as work is continued. It is that hope coupled by the warm and evil feelings of nostalgia that led me to buy this game. Don;t worry if you haven;t played Dungeon Keeper 1 and/or 2. It's really not necessary. But I can promise you, when this game reaches it's full potential, I believe it will outshine those other dungeon management games.

reviewText: What's to say about it that hasn't already been said? It's the spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper. It's got all the same qualities, has an interesting balance between traps and spells, but it doesn't seem like it has enough to be... 100% perfect. For now, give this a try if you love Dungeon Keeper, it feels like it, it looks like it, it plays very well if you have an up to date computer, and there's the benifit of more comming out in updates.

Gamemodes:

*SURVIVAL MODE*
Anyway, I feel that the survival gamemode is too lag-intensive, also there is not enough time to rebuild your defenses and stuff, I had to toggle infinite gold and build midas doors to support the super lag intensive waves of dwarves, ember spirits, behememoths, pigs, and as such, also, I was like how is a person who does not us ethe debug menu survive this? Makes it feel like a tower defense game with endless mode xD
*CAMPAGIAN*
Want more! I want to kill more goodly heroes! well I felt lazy in the 2nd episode of the campagin and spawned juggernauts in the core xD. Well, enjoyed the story and how its a half tutorial while strategically positioning your units to destroy the enimes miserable forces, feels so good to swarm them and they die in seconds, also currently there wasnt any sort of time limit to the campagian so far so I liked the casual feel to it.
*SANDBOX*
Ah, my favourite gamemode, you should know why. Play this gamemode if you want to experiment dungeon builds, also if you dig the wrong block you always have the replacment block, so dont worry, buidl your desired dungeon!
*MULTIPLAYER*
Well... havent tried it yet due to bad internet, sorry []

Pros:
-Like dungeon keeper
-Nice graphics
-smooth gamplay(For me)

Cons:
-Early acess, not much to campagain just yet
-Some glitchy pathing here and there
-Sometimes monsters just derp out or run in circle


Overall:
This game is still in early acess, so don't really expect that much, but really excited for the whole game and expect this to be another sucess like dungeon keeper!
7/10

reviewText:
First off, great work Stubterranean games! I've been a backer of this project from its inception, and other than the occasional 5 minute bout every six months to get a feel for how things were coming along I've all but avoided every piece of news about the game in the hopes that I wouldn't spoil myself for release.

I'm a long time fan of the Dungeon Keeper series and fondly remember as a 10 year old sinking entire school holidays into figuring out how to deal with digging into clusters of level 10 Samurais. Dungeon Keeper has and always will have a place on my hard drive alongside many of the Bullfrog classics, back when Peter Molyneux could keep up with his big ideas. How the mighty have fallen! Anyway my review ;

It's no secret that this game is a spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper, and while I want to keep in mind that it is it's own beast and I shouldn't directly compare for the sake of biasing myself, inevitably, and inescapably, this is something that will be part of this review. Thankfully whether that's right or wrong, WftO in my opinion has nailed the atmosphere extremely well. The background hum of dank dungeon corridors and the deep, thumping beat of your dungeon heart, alongside your insidious sounding, witty assistant has thrown me back to my schooldays.

Dungeon design itself I have mixed feelings about. There doesn't seem to be as much of an incentive to place down traps or dig your dungeon out in areas to encompass rooms and a necessity to mine out entire areas to make use of the tiles you get is apparant.

I feel like the actual map sizes don't compliment the number of rooms given particularly well, even if the rooms themselves are well thought out in terms of theme and function. Something as simple as converting particular rooms and their functions into room addons may be able to accomodate this where it makes sense - The Sanctuary's functions placed in the centre of a library with an expensive altar for example, or unlocking an arena pen to attract your Beast Master which you could then place on the grounds of an expansive and somewhat barren Beast Lair to fill it out.
I would assume at least for the campaign, fiddling with map sizes would require a horrendous amount of work, so combining rooms with a usefulness that seems somewhat saturated would possibly be a good direction. Some rooms feel a little empty and as a whole the sheer number of room types doesn't translate well to the room you tend to have on each map.

The maps themselves from a campaign standpoint are well thought out, the variation of mission types is welcome and I'm glad as it brings a particular flavour to each map which allows you to apply your creativity in different ways. Dungeon planning was always a big part of Dungeon Keeper and I feel like the variation offered in each map is similar enough to give you that lets get to work
recommended: without making everything too samey and keeping you on your toes somewhat.\n\nMy biggest gripe is creatures and battle. I have found myself a few times leaving rally flags sitting up against an enemy keeper after all but wiping each other out

reviewText:
It is definately a good attempt at a Dungeon Keeper. The problem is the game lag quite a bit in certain areas. Also the mini map is about as usefull as a butter knife. Other problems is that the game has some user interface issues. For example the keeper will ask you to click on the flashing tile to place an object however there is no queue as to where this tile might  be and until you find it you cannot click other actions. With no feedback you are left in the darkness about what to do next.

In the current state I would not recommend this to anyone who is new to the DK series. However if like me you have been waitting far too long to once afain wreck havoc on the goody two shoes in the overworld this will plug the gap that has been aching in our dark hearts for years.

The current issues are resolvable and I hope the developers can take this from good to great with the updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dungeon Keeper was a blast and if, like me, you have played it recently, you'll see how far ahead of its time it was (or how little we have progress in gameplay). The only things that give away its age are the visuals and the clunkiness of the UI. So, when I purchased WFTO I was expecting improved graphics and a modern streamline and responsive UI.
This is not (yet) the case.
Aesthetically it's quite ugly and would feel right if it had been released in the 2005.
The interaction is dated, zero feedback loop, sluggish and unclear. On a sidenote I wonder what prompted the devs to chose a 3D mouse cursor instead of a 60 fps hardware cursor, at least if the game lags, give user real time mouse.
The game is labelled as a beta but plays as an early alpha so be warned.
Like its predecessor, this game has great potential so I hope to see a lot of polishing in the next few month.

reviewText:
Ths is the true spritual successor to the Dungeon Keeper series -- all the way down to the same voice actor for the announcer!

However, the system requirements are so high (or perhaps it's a lack of optimization for mid-range systems?) that the game becomes unplayable on larger maps.

I *VERY* much want to play this game four dozens -- perhaps hundreds -- of hours, but can't even continue the campaign without a substantial system upgrade to bring it into the stable 20-30FPS range.   It's 5-10FPS on large maps for me right now.  Maybe next year?

So in summary:  If you have a high-end system, PLAY THIS GAME!  It's like DK3 would/should have been... lots of new toys, traps, and depth.

reviewText:
To all you ex-Dungeon Keeper 2 players looking to reignite your love of the game....Buy this game! But beware things are a little different this time.....

At first, I was weary of the deviations from DK2 (of which there are many), and wasn't exactly sure if I liked it or not, but over time, I've come to believe this game is actually an improvement on the original.

Pros:
+Relive DK2 fun in a new and challenging way.
+Map editors
+Great game mechanics (skills trees, mana locking, sanctuarys etc.)
+Multiplayer

Cons:
-Relentless AI (surely this can be toned down?)
-The add crash or glitch (particulary on multiplayer)

The single player is great fun, and a great way to learn how the new game functions. My main grievance is just how relentless the AI is. It really is ridiculously hard sometimes.

Features such as mana locking and skills tree seem annoying at first, but you begin to realise that it's a mechanic that actually makes gameplay far more enjoyable in the long run.

For me the multiplayer is the best (and sometime worst) part of the game. This is the closest I've come to reliving those glory days of LAN'ing DK2 with friends, so I can't recommend this game enough for this reason alone. My main frustration comes from the odd crash when a large battle starts (which lets be honest, was far more regular on the orginal DK2). The game is far less geared toward defence (compared with DK2), so rather than lengthly stalemates, games can be won/lost within half an hour or so.

In short, this game is will delight those familiar with DK2, but will still provide a new challenge with it's tweaking on the mechanics. There are still the odd glitches which need to be ironed out, but these are few and far between, and don't effect the overall enjoyment of the game.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Avid Dungeon Keeper fan, started playing it just 6 years old. I've owned this game since it first dropped on the workshop, I've followed it's progress throughout, occasionally launching the game to have a quick peek then waiting till it was done.

Finally let myself play the campaign now I figured it would be polished enough months after release.

Bugs, just bugs everywhere. First impression, stutter before the menu loaded, then the button disappeared whenever I hovered over them, then when I finally manager to change screen resolution I had to force shut the application and restart to get it working again. On load the second time menu items white checkerboard everywhere, glitching and lagging into the campaign menu. I so want this game to be good.

Into the first level, seems fairly okay, dialogue lines are being repeated randomly, adnimations are a bit wooden, but whatever, nostalgia overload - graphics are pretty awesome and Richard Ridings sounds awesome - I could see it being stellar. Second level, well I had to play the first one again for whatever reason, but when it eventually loaded the first condition of with selecting a Vein of Evil" couldn't be done because it wasn't an option on the panel
date: trying to exit the game I had to force quit because once again the menu wouldn't load.\n\nI can't believe after a couple of years this game is still unplayable. I've seen how much work the devs have put in
recommended: but I just get the impression it launched too soon (maybe for cashflow reasons)
hoursPlayed: and it's several revisions in and still pretty unplayable

reviewText:

Review updates on 26th Dec 2014 :  the latest patch provides 3 campaign maps to play , a lot of improved texture on rooms and creature animation in general , with almost fully functional unit combats and rooms, the game is shaping up into an amazing dungeon management game that screams with the 'DUNGEON KEEPER SEQUEL ' vibe  . If you are fans of the good old bullfrog games such as theme hospital, theme parks, DK , you will be absolutely in love with this game , which I would suggest you get this game right now to support the developers .  Else you can wait for the full game release which is currently scheduled to be released in early 2015


Was a big fan of the dungeon keeper series , can't tell you how excited I am when I heard about this game . Missed the chance to pledge for the project on kickstarter , the moment it released on Steam I got it right away .    The developers of the game are really hardworking , they have updates on the game quite frequently and new information every week and often hold live stream sessions on twitch.tv to answer questions from the players .  They are really passionate about the game and its that enthusiasm you had to admire .  Throughout all these times , I have seen massive improvement in the game, from  barely playable stage to fully voiced tutorial maps , dozen of rooms to build and constant improvement on the creature A.I  . There aren't that many of maps and stages to try out yet , but every penny I put on the game is very worth it . Most importantly , you get all the DK vibes from the game !

reviewText:
At first and foremost I have been a Dungeon Keeper 1 & 2 fan since I play computer games! I think that this fact is pretty relevant for this review. It is tha digging and room building that I loved quite muche these days and still do. Besides being the evil guy is always quite tempting, isn't it? Of course it is! Therefore I am really happy that War For The Overworld managed to breathe new life into this uniue genre. What follows is a list about different game mechanics that I like and don't like.

Rooms:
WFTO managed to bring the rooms that the player built in Dungeon Keeper back to life and developes it further. The player needs ingame to dig for new space and build rooms in that space. These rooms vary in size and purpose even more than they did in Dungeon Keeper. The player uses these rooms to attract humanoids and beasts, trains them and makes them happy or uses rooms to increase the own power with spells.
Rooms get 1+ from me!

Spells:
What I like is that WFTO did't just copy rooms and spells from Dungeon Keeper into the game, but created many unique spells that come in form of, well spells but also in potions that can be made in certain rooms. Also rituals let the player feel quite evil and unstoppable while he fullfills the ritual simulatiously with preventing the heroes from docking at the door.
Also Spells get 1+ from me!

Traps, Weapons, Buildables:
The player not only builds rooms, but also traps and other stuff to make the underground its home and its enemies hell. The buildable stuff that the player can choose from varies a lot, but I dont want to tell you about this for spoiler reasons. See youself and have fun!
Buildables get 1+ from me!

Downside!:
WFTO also has its problems, at leat with my computer. At a certain point ingame it starts to lag and can be stopped by turning down the graphics. I believe that this is a problem that will be solved as I write this review, because the game just released to version 1.0 and will be updated further.

Conclusion:
WFTO is the Dungeon Keeper successor that I always wished to get! Well okay I cant get to the overworld which I wished for after Dungeon Keeper 2, but damnit! We have enough games for beating somebody up in the overworld.
In my opinion WFTO is a musthave game for fans and newcomers!

I have only played War for the Overworld for 55 minutes, and i'm already in love.
Incase you never knew, War for the Overworld is the spiritual successor to the Dungeon Keeper franchise after the company that made Dungeon Keeper (Bullfrog) just disappeared.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access done properly and a game that is respectful of it's influences. Regular updates, assets and game play done to the highest standard. This is one of the few games on Steam I can recommend picking up early. However, I wouldn't recommend playing it early - what is there presently s very solid and produced to a high standard, but developing a game properly takes time and this is more of an investment in my eyes. A game that is shaping up to be fantastic but due to a focus on doing things properly and promptly as opposed to just quickly, functionality is still lacking compared to what the final product should offer. That said, patching and updates are both regular and frequent and what is already in place is very enjoyable and picking it up on the cheap now is a definite good call.

If you enjoyed Dungeon Keeper - and who didn't? - this is well worth your cash-moniez.

reviewText: So far, this game is mostly what I hoped it would be. I waited until the bumpy release to buy it, and so far, I haven't run into any bugs other than an occassional spike in lag when I use the ritual which reveals the whole map at once for ten seconds.\nThe art is mostly pleasing, though I tend to like how the hero faction's theme was designed more than the standard Underlord theme. The game so far does a good job at introducing you to key concepts without making the tutorial seem dull, even for an RTS/Dungeon Keeper 1/2 player like me. The campaign can be challenging at times, but a little easy at others. As of now, there are few skirmish maps, but there will be a patch soon that will supposedly add quite a number of maps, which has me pleased. The best thing, though, would be to release a map editor to conjoin with the steam workshop or something so that the game makers can allow the community to create their own maps.\nFor personal tastes, I like and have a hard time accepting this game at times. I like how diverse you can make your forces on the campaign, but limiting things in skirmish maps based on technology (Sin) trees seems silly in the sense that if I play long enough, I'd like to have access to everything available, rather than be limited in what I can do longterm. Along with that, I have a problem with the types of available creatures in the game- nothing seems to be like an end-game" level creature other than the super-creatures

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a massive fan of the Dungeon Keeper games, I cannot express the joy I felt when stumbling upon this.

It's everything I wanted to see in a new DK game, and more. New rooms, new creatures, new game mechanics, and of course not to mention new graphics, it's really exciting to see where this project is going because they've done a damn good job this far in development already.

Those unfamiliar with the game-style in question should consider researching the Dungeon Keeper series (or just watch a gameplay video) for this is no ordinary RTS, it is one of the few games falling under the category of RTS/FPS hybrid: feel like touring the layout of your dungeon from the perspective of your minions? Well go ahead and tap right into their skulls! Admiring the detail the developers have clearly put into the various dungeon rooms from up close is a feeling no other game can replicate for me, a particular reason which makes the franchise as a whole so unique.

I would buy the game twice I'm that happy with it, but I'm broke and have no need for a second copy therefore I will not be doing that

reviewText:
After playing this game for about 10 hours, I feel I can write a faily solid review in relativity to the state the game is now in under release.

This game is a surprisingly amazing throwback and spiritual successor to Bullfrog's series Dungeon keeper. The gameplay is a breath of fresh air in an industry over saturated with Indie Devs creating stale replications of more popular games.

This game features dungeon building (which is amazingly satisfying), RTS elements. And economic balancing. Kind of a Towns/RTS if you will. The game features 4 modes, Campaign. Survival, Skirmish, and sandbox. (Multiplayer skirmish)

Campain acts as a story setting and tutorial for the game's research system, building and running your dungeon effectively. With brilliantly evil voice acting, fun and exciting missions that challenge your abilities as an Underlord. Campaign will keep you busy for hours and help you refine your skills as an underlord.

Skirmish is unfinished but the basic format for a skirmish game is 2 or more Underlords facing off in an attempt to destroy eachother's dungeon core (Larger player games are being worked on) This game gives you a fully unlocked Veins of evil tree to research the rooms nessesary to defeat the opposing player.

Survival is very much what is says on the box, and like skirmish, is still relatively under construction. Survival places you in a premade dungeon and gives you 3 lanes to defend where opposing heroes will try and breach your dungeon's defences and destroy your core. Sounds simple right? Its hard. Really hard. Good luck.

And sandbox, a dungeon building wonderland, where the game gives you the freedom to construct a dungeon of ludicrous size, and this mode, as free as it is, will only last you a certain amount of time, as the lack of enemy contact makes it feel.. empty at best after all of your rooms have been made.

At the time of review I can give this game my approval and definetly recommend this to any person who is a fan or the original Dungeon keeper series. And anyone who is a fan of RTS and Towns" Style games. But do not be afraid to try if you normally stray away from these styles of games! This game has somthing for everyone

i was a huge fan and put many hours into Dungeon Keeper. that being said.. i love what's been done so far, but MAJOR elements (imo) are still missing.

you need to be able to beat your minions into doing things they'd rather not.

you need to be able to lock them in a room and have them keep working in fear of more beatings, even as they starve to death. like a good minion should. it may seem harsh, but this is the mind set every good dungeon keeper should have.

reviewText:
It's Dungeon Keeper 3....and it's AWESOME!


The good:

War for the Overworld is Dungeon Keeper 3 in all but name! Richard Ridings (of the original Dungeon Keeper games) is back voicing the mentor, telling you to get building glorious dungeons to house your minions. The Empire is banging on your dungeon doors and you need all the help you can get.

This all add's up to a lot of fun than fans of the original Dungeon Keeper games never thought we would see again all because a small but very solid dev team Kickstarted this game and I'm so very glad they did.

There has been a constant stream of patches and interaction from the devs since I purchased the game and to be honest, they are putting big comapny names to shame in how fast they are to respond to issues.

The bad:

The game is still a bit rough around the edges and unfinnished in parts. Certain parts of the game have yet to be finnished fully (such as skirmish mode which is to be added later this year) and there is still a lot of ingame tweaking done by the devs. Save games can also be a risk as a quick patch can render a save file unuseable (though thankfully it only means restarting a level). It's also one of those games where you'll find yourself binge playing through the whole thing if you're not careful.



So..should you buy this game? Most certainly. The main campaign is finnished and multiplayer works. The unfinnished parts are just..extras. It's great fun and it's one of those rare titles where the devs are acctually doing what they say they will do.

Now get to work Underlord!

reviewText:
If your evil and/or sadistic this is a must have :D


GAMEPLAY
If you have played the dungeon keeper games youl know what to expect from this game and its bang on the money but also refreshingly new. You are a Dungeon Ke..... Lord and you build a dungeon by digging and placeing room tiles as well as traps fortifications, cast spells ect ect.
You Dungeon attracts minions to do your bidding that use your rooms too....

1.Work (Build you traps research sins and so on)
2.Train ( grow levels and become better fighter)
3. To live of (eating, sleeping and keeping themselves happy)


VOICE ACTING

The Voice acting in game is EPIC nuff said


CAMPAIGN

The levels a well designed and feel very different with different chalanges and ways to overcome said chalanges. The game is not as storey driven as some other games (say starcraft 2) but i feel it is still pretty good.


Pros

+Real dungeon keeper like gameplay
+Great level design
+great creature art
+great Room art
+EPIC voice acting
+Dark feel (It's Good to be Bad")
+Sadistic parody sort of humour
+ Fan funded fan made
+promising new game dev

Cons

- 13 levels seems a bit few
- mp is not that replayable (for me at least)
- you can't help missing your fav dungeon keeper creatures (bile demon

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit (12 June 2014): Since version 0.4.2 the OS X build and the Linux build are working well again! The game is also much more stable as it was when I wrote this review. The developers now also actively involve the users of WFTO in testing the game; they now often release previews in which the newest features and fixes are available at a seperate beta-branch at Steam. WFTO also works well if you have a low-end-machine, so don't worry about that. And if it does not work right on your low-end-machine; the developers will do more optimatization to WFTO in the comming versions, so it even runs faster as it already does! :)

This will maybe be even better then Dungeon Keeper; it now has a lot of rooms, many characters and very nice graphics. The 20 euros are worth it! The developers give everyone even acces to pre-beta, so you can test the newest content and maybe even report bugs to help the developers finisching this game ;) They publish at least once a week news on their main website about the development progress and answer a lot of questions on their forums. Never saw that kind of developers with so much humor! :)

They have fixed many bugs and crashes in the last months; I can surely say it's playable, you will sometimes maybe see a tiny little bug or a very rarely crash (got a few ones so far,) but you can play the levels like a charm. WFTO even contains a debug mode and debug console with which you can mess around with the game :)

There are known problems about that you can only play an old version of WFTO on Mac OSX at the moment, but this is not caused by WFTO itself; it is a bug at the Unity side and the Unity team is working on resolving this issue for everyone, so you will probably soon be able to play the latest version of this game on MAC OSX soon! See here for more updates on this: https://forum.subterraneangames.com/threads/488-osx-version-of-the-game-is-not-up-to-date.4981/

They are still working on polishing the UI, AI, graphics etc (but you can play it very well at the moment!). But it's worth to buy it now already and help the developers to finish the game, but the game is now also a little bit cheaper then after the release!!! Grab your chance now and get this game Keeper/Underlord!

reviewText:
Any fan of the Ol' Good Dungeon Keeper series MUST play this game.
Anyone who have waited for DK 3 MUST play this game.

The developers have brought back what DK series were shining at, and brought everything back with the original playability, with crisp gorgeous HD graphics.

The original evil concierge voice that was in DK2 is here, with occational fun punch lines during play - although they tend to repeat what is said not 5 minutes ago.

The graphics and in-game props are almost similar to that of DK2, along with the same pickaxe holding hand. - But in higher polygon count and higher texture quality, and the devs. have managed to have the feel of DK series.

The game play goes same, from the ol' trusty imp slapping, lightning spells that fries whatnots, to that of 5X5 tiles which bother those with OCDs (like myself).

Well made, well played.

reviewText:
[Review written for 1.3]

Short Review:Engaging RTS / dungeon management game where you get to play the bad guys.
Negative reviews are primarily concerned with WFTO at launch. Game is fully polished and well-optimised now, which makes for a much more enjoyable experience. Worth the full price, extremely worth during a sale.

(Very) Long Review:
I backed this during the Kickstarter crowdfunding phase, and was an avid fan of DK1 and 2. Bias confirmation confirmed, but this review is as objective as I can make it.

OverviewWar for the Overworld is the spiritual successor to the cult hit Dungeon Keeper, a series by Bullfrog (later snapped up by EA - which is why DK3 never. ;_;).
You play as an 'Underlord', a wibbly wobbly non-corporeal being that seals its essence in a Dungeon Core (the room you start with in every game). Lose that and you lose the game; protect it at all costs.
But in order to enact your will (and defend said Core), you gain access to an assortment of rooms,

The Good
- You're the bad guy!

- Very polished. Backers and early buyers remember the... fiasco that was WFTO's launch (although they did explain why it released the way it did, which was understandable); it's come a long way since then. Virtually all bugs have been fixed, many quality-of-life features have been implemented/improved and the optimisation is much better.

- Unique. Although a successor to DK, there's nothing else like this on the market at the moment. WFTO isn't a carbon copy of DK either; it has its own fantasy, creatures and ideas (most notably, Potions and Rituals).

- Build your own Dungeon. One of the major attractions, you can build your Dungeon however you feel like (within the constraints of the map terrain, of course). If you want a massive open-plan ground, meticulously divided rooms full of doorways and corridors, then you can do it. (A more recent addition was Wall prop efficiency; to offset the fact you have less building space, rooms with reinforced walls will operate more effectively.)

- Playstyle variety [outside of the Campaign]. Every game, you'll start with no abilities or rooms unlocked, spending Sins (points) in a three-column Tech Tree to unlock stuff. You can rush for a specific tree's Titan, or you can spread Sins across all three trees. That said, I don't think it's perfect (see below).

- Entertaining. With Richard Ridings as your Mentor (the same VA for the DK Mentor) and the dark, tongue-in-cheek (and occasionally just plain silly) humour, it'll catch you out once in a while.That, with the excellent(ly awful) voice acting for the good guys makes for fun outside of the gameplay.

The Bad
- Hotkeys. Hotkey support was enabled a while back, but the lack of visibility is a significant issue to learn hotkeys, especially if you're trying to micro combat / efficiency. Could easily be fixed by displaying the relevant hotkey in ability tooltips.

- The AI. It's alright, but once you get to grips with the game, it becomes a lot easier to fight against. Also, there's no difficulty mode for the campaign; although the early missions are newbie-friendly, the difficulty curve rises quite significantly, particularly if you're new to this genre.

- Hidden / unexplained mechanics. Following on from the previous point, the game introduces many additional utilities you can make use of. That in and of itself is a good thing; the lack of introduction and usage of them isn't great. There's still a few rituals and potions I never make use of, while others are pretty overpowered for their investment. There are user-written guides that provide in-depth explanations, but it shouldn't really be the place of the community to tell you how something functions in the first place.

- Meta playstyles Lack of depth to Tech Tree. Having tested a defensive strategy against Master AI, I can confirm that defensive strats do indeed work (Avarice + WDs, all I'm saying), though I can't see them being as effective vs players. Nevertheless, Although there are options and optimal choices do vary from map to map, I still feel more could be done to promote tech / build diversity. Possibly passive buffs (and nerfs?) for certain units when you invest into certain trees, or passives that only activate from speccing into multiple trees to complement your playstyle.

- RAM usage. I have 8GB RAM (DDR3, meh clock speed), but on larger maps I will start to lag; it's still playable, but everything goes slower and commands won't always register. For optimal experience you'll want 12 or 16GB, but it's fine on small/medium sized maps.

ConclusionCongrats for getting this far!
Overall, I would strongly recommend picking this up (especially if it's on sale, but the devs definitely earned the money asked). Many of the negative reviews were released at launch, present issues that have since been addressed in virtually all cases. Most of the bad points are fairly minor, primarily to do with communication and visibility.

Yes, it's not Dungeon Keeper 3; but that's fine. I personally believe it's better that WFTO is its own game, drawing inspiration from DK but not trying to become it.

reviewText:
Old Review: For anyone who has a love for the Dungeon Keeper games of old (not including EA's recent disgustingly obvious cashgrab with the Dungeon Keeper game for iOS) then this is the game for you.  They even have Richard Ridings doing the narration as he did for DK1 & 2!! It's like Dungeon Keeper all over again but without the soul sucking presence of a corporate publisher involved to make it suck with their stupid marketing surveys. Awesome!

So I finally got around to playing the official 1.0 release of this game that launched back in April? I think, and I have to say that it feels pretty good to know that my original review during its time in SEA still holds up to the last twenty-ish or so hours of gameplay I've experienced in the past couple days.  Even though I've yet to encounter something that even comes close to the awesomeness of the Horned Reaper character from the original DK series, WFO is definitely the DK successor I've been wanting since my obsession with replaying DK2 ended so many years ago.

One negative point brought up in the more critical reviews that I've read so far stated something like there were too many spells, rituals, constructs, etc and that they themselves only needed one or two spells to complete the game so every other option they didn't use at the time was considered to be unnecessary content.  I agree that there are a lot more options than there ever was with the previous DK series but all the same, I find that having a lot of variety helps the replay value of the game.

As much as I hate to say it, I do think that the narrator is a bit too chatty some times and as much as I love Richard Ridings from the DK series, it did get to be a bit much at times.   Yet all the same, I can't blame the developers for wanting to get as much mileage out of the legacy asset of RR's voice as they possibly could because so much of the DK vibe comes from his voice alone.

So anyway, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the Dungeon Keeper series or to anyone who thinks the game looks interesting because it is really well done and I find myself easily losing hours while playing, which is exactly what I would expect from the spiritual successor of Dungeon Keeper.

reviewText:
Hello
As someone who liked the old dungeon keeper games, when I saw this game go on kickstarter I was very excited about it. This genre of game is unique in a sense that you are the evil. You build a kingdom but you cannot control those who join your cause and your style of building defines what archetype of mobs join you.

I must say that for a game that has just released it is to be expected to have a slightly buggy experience, however in this case there really are bugs everywhere. The game feels unfinished. When you open up the menu after installing and click multiplayer the first thing that prompts up is, this will be patched in. The same happens when you click survival mode, and when you click skirmish there is a shocking three maps. The only fully functional mode as of right now is the campaign. This was already a huge letdown, minutes after finishing my download.

I didn't let it phase me and I went for the campaign. Now from the very start I ran into bugs and problems. As a former dungeon keeper player and with many games behind my belt I have a good idea on how to play games. Now this is very important because the tutorial is horrible. They barely scrape the surface of what buildings do, there is no explanation what so ever how the controls work. I was unable to move my camera, had issues with targetting. You'd figure okay, I will read the tooltips but frankly, there are no useful tooltips anywhere in the game to be found. Mostly there are placeholders from an early alpha build. shrine prop siege" doesn't tell me what it does? The big thing for this game is the micro management of the buildings

reviewText:
I like the faithfulness of this game to the original. They kept the flavor of the original game, making it easy to make the transition. So far as I could tell, there's all the same elements of the original game, dungeon building, room optimizing, cheating your minions out of their pay, slapping and torturing them, etc.

There's also some very good new features, like control groups and invisible-fence-for-imps, that were missing from the original. The graphical update makes it a very nice looking game, although by no means cutting edge or demanding.

This does mean, however, that the game is not much of a change from the original. There's no radically new gameplay, just some tweaks, a graphical update and a new story.

Also, the minimap is unnecessarity pixelated, and the game uses so much memory! It uses 2.5GB more memory than Tomb Raider 2013, and about 1GB more memory than vanilla Rome II. I can't imagine what all that memory is used for, since Rome II handles more units and has better texture. Given this and some other reviews, I'm inclined to think that optimization is not very good, and systems with slower/less RAM will stutter due to paging issues.

reviewText:
As a huge dungeon keeper fan I was very excited to see a game produced which is clearly a huge tribute to an amazing classic. However at the time of first looking at this game it had mostly negative reviews, so I stayed away. Checking back recently I noticed that suddenly the reviews were hugely positive, with people praising the developers most recent updates (1.1 and 1.2) and saying the game was now polished and worth playing. Due to the Halloween sale I picked it up to give it a try. I am not disappointed!

This game takes all the things that made dungeon keeper great and maintains the legacy. It felt so familiar to me that it was like playing dungeon keeper all over again. The campaign has some challenging levels to keep you on your toes and a great entertaining narrated voice over (From the same voice actor that did DK2!!)

A small gripe I have is how insane the AI is, on skirmish they somehow always end up with 3-4x as many minions as you within minutes. I am not sure if this is because I suck or because the AI is just mentally good but it does make my desire to get all the achievements a huge challenge!

Overall this game is very polished and any dungeon keeper fan should try it and love it! One thing I have noticed which makes me incredibly supportive (Supportive enough to write a review, which I have never done before) Is that the developers listen! every review I check the developers have commented saying that they will work on that, they seem to genuinely care for the player base, which these days is a rare thing! So Kudos devs for listening to players and actually acting on it! You have a happy customer from me and another positive review. Keep it up!
voteText: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Before we even get in to gameplay - I feel I have to point out just how much time and effort the dev team have put into this game since the days of early release. When the game first came out in beta - touted as the spiritual successor to DK2, it was full of bugs, glitches, frustrations and was pretty unplayable.
Fast forward to now, and we have what's basically a different game to when it started; with huge patches, and now an official expansion pack. What a journey - and I have to give credit where credit is due to the developers, in regards to their time, effort, and the way they've interacted and responded to the community feedback.

The game itself - in my opinion is everything we could have hoped for, if there ever was an official DK3. Updated graphics, new (very inventive) units, spells, skills; but of course all the original charm of the series we love, including the voice work! :)
Really enjoying playing this, and presume I will contunue to do so for some time. To all fans of dungeon sims - don't hesitate. I don't think you'll be disappointed! Welcome back Underlords.

reviewText:
WftO is the first game in one and a half decades to get the Dungeon Sim right. It's tonnes of fun, and brings a great mix of old features from the old classics, improvements to the formula and new ideas.

As of today, there are quite a few bugs, but the team are squashing them at an astounding rate. Given that this is an Indie team's first game, a few teething issues seems expected. On the other hand considering this is an Indie team's first game, the quality and scope are very impressive.

I've followed this game since I backed it on Kickstarter in 2012, and honestly, I'm impressed by what's been achieved, and proud to have been a part of it.

reviewText:
'Dungeon Keeper'. Yeah. You can't escape the fact that this is the game that you buy if you wanted a Dungeon Keeper 3 (or a decent DK2).  You will typically start the game looking for a creature portal, building rooms for sleeping, eating and training, and finding the starting gold vain. Nothing new there.

But this game stands strong in it's own right. Obviously, it just isn't quite DK. Hating it for this seems to be a hobby for many fans. But the game deserves to be treated as though it stands on it's own: and it certainly can. If DK had never existed, this game would be hailed as an innovative marvel. Instead, it is simply a fun, workable game using the same formula.

An early example of a nice little innovation is the Tavern building: Minions will pay some of their wages back to you for cooked food and beer, but you need to keep it stocked, giving an interesting strategic choice. Things such as this give the game a feeling of depth without making it micro-manage hell.

The game is worth the money. You will have fun playing a dungeon-building strategy game. It is not DK. Get over it.

reviewText:
Introduction/Foreword:

I am one of the many (or not so many? Dunno...) that owns this game since the Bedrock Beta so I can tell you pretty well some negative and positive things about this game, but mostly negative....

First and foremost I must admit that the guys at Subterrenean Games are working hard and passionate, however there are - as mentioned before - some very negative things that destroy the enjoyability of this game for me and will probably also for you...


About the Bedrock Beta:
The Beta was actually an entire mess, there was almost nothing that actually really worked it even crashed regularly and gameplay lagged as hell...
So that what was actually called a beta" was actually a public alpha version
date:
but this wouldnt be a major problem if Subterrenean wouldnt have rushed the game out.


At release:
The game has been hastly released with alot of bugs from the "beta"
recommended: apart of the lack of optimization for systems other than the developers.  The next disappointment was that who purchased the underlord edition didnt got everything as advertised. The soundtrack for example was missing and there was also no advertised guide. The soundtrack was added later (you buy something but you dont get the product you paid for...)
hoursPlayed:
dunno about the guide and I also dont care anymore...


After release:
It took approximately 2 major updates (1.1 and 1.2) and several minor patches before
voteText:
so that the game could be called "somehow" - and only somehow - a working game.


The latest major update (version 1.3) with a retrospective view:
Well

reviewText:
Finally! A game that does the Dungeon Keeper spirit proud after so many failed attempts by others! This really is the equivalent of the much beloved DK series that I was a huge fan of when I was a little girl/young teenager.

It did take me a bit to get used to the UI and general game changes, and it could use some minor tweaks and fixes but nothing jumps out at me as a major issue that can't or won't be fixed, I don't know of any game, including the original DK games that didn't have some issues. It's not 'exactly' the same of course but close enough to make it great!

To me the couple of minor issues I did run into/noticed were a non-issue to me and I felt didn't take away from the gameplay in any significant manner. The developers are as passionate about the DK series as the player and it really does show! It's evident that they're on top of trying to fix the issues left and I just can't recommend this game enough times!

reviewText:
Updated Review

I tend not to like games that stay in early access for 2 years as this one did then gets released unfinished. It defeats the point of early access in my book.

It is now July 2015, 4 months after War for the Overworld was released and it finally has enough Skirmish maps to make it worth playing in single player. An update to Unity 5 seems to have improved performance too.

It has enough units, powers and spells to keep most dungeon keeper fans happy, and it brings enough of its own tricks to the table so it cannot be accused of being a straight forward clone of the old classic.

If it has any problem it is that it has too many rooms and monsters for most maps, you will find your self without the room to the build them all. So your going to have to choose what you want and what you do not want.

Previously I recommended this game but only just, stating a lack of maps and other unfinished features meant you would be left waiting to play it because it was not finished.

Also, previously, I said 7 out of 10 on metacritics user score was about right, it is now at 7.3 and rising on metacritics because the game is finally playable. In it is current state it is worth about an 8.

Though the campaign pretty much sucks with its timers and shows a distinct lack of imagination, mind you so do the new maps.

What is it with devs these days and their symetrical maps ?

Recommended.... finally...
voteText: 17 of 30 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Like any Dungeon Keeper fanboy I was excited when news of this game reached my ears. Here was a promise to pay homage to a favorite game of mine from when I was way younger, a game that has had few of its like since it came out.

This is what I expected: A dungeon building simulator where you build your lair, gather minions, train them, build defenses and then storm the opposition. To say that this is not what I received would be a lie but the thing is the game delivers things so clunkily that all enjoyment is simply sucked out of it.

Yes, you do build your own fully functioning dungeon... assuming you can figure out the actual mechanics of the game, that being the logistics behind the rooms and how the minions interract with them. You can have lots of fun reading through half finished tool tips and placeholders and see if you can make sense of it.

You do employ a workforce of diabolical minions... but again the game is not exactly forthcoming on details on how they function inside your dungeon and in combat which leads to cluster♥♥♥♥ combat scenarios in which you just pile your guys together and hope they come out on top.

You do conquer realms and bring ruination to your enemies... but through a story that appears to be missing half of its cutscenes and animations and this is assuming that the game doesn't crash or go through constant memory leaks.

I guess you could say that this game delivers everything that was expected, but it is done so badly that all the fun gets lost behind somewhere. There's a lot of good ideas here but the game doesn't take its time to explain how they work and some ideas never get used at all.

reviewText:
*revision*
Patch 1.1 took care of most of the issues that were keeping me from enjoying the game; i'm having quite a bit of fun now.  i appreciate the continued attention to this game and i can now honestly recommend it!

As with most people who own this game, I'm a huge fan of the Dungeon Keeper games and was looking forward to this one.  In it's current state however, i cannot suggest this game to anyone.  Clearly unfinished, this game has too many glaring issues;

-terrible AI
-glitchy/slow UI
-crashes
-walls/ dungeon setup becomes useless as fortified walls break down easily
-Campaign levels are short in supply and lack difficulty; little strategy is needed to blow through all 13.

WFTO has alot of potential but seems as though it was rushed to release once the developers hit the halfway mark.  With some tweaks and updates this game could easily be worth the $30 price.  At the moment however, I regret purchasing this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been waiting for sooo long a new Dungeon Keeper (3) and this is the game, even if it is not the official license.
Dungeon Keeper 2 was my favorite game, and this one is good,

BUT this is not optimised at all and the game is hardly laggy, there are only 1 map with a story and ennemies (lot's o' but still), 1 tutorial map which is also buggy, there are a lot of graphics bugs, AND finaly there are 3 sandboxes without ennemies.
But you have to know that this is a very very EARLY ALPHA TEST GAME !!! DO NOT EXPECT ANY FULL CONTENT, because there are not for now.

Thus I LOVE Dungeon Keeper but this game is not full yet,  and know that I understand that ( even if they had 14 years to make this game ).

reviewText: I held off getting this game for awhile because I figured it was another cheap Dungeon Keeper knockoff. Now that I've played it I can definitely say that it's a worthy successor to DK2. More than just a graphical upgrade, with the addition of quality of life improvements like Warbands and Impasses, useful spells like Replacement Earth, and new mechanics like rituals, alchemy, and titans, War for the Overworld is actually a nice improvement over the Dungeon Keeper games, pretty much fixing all the things that were annoying or hard to manage while still adding new complexities and strategies. Skirmish mode and multiplayer make a welcome return as well.\n\nSome people report that the game is buggy, but I have only run into a couple small glitches, mostly in the form of minion animations that don't look quite right.

reviewText:
A true successor for Dungeon Keeper 2 :

Cons :

No more romance between Mr. Skeleton on the electric chair and SM Mistress :(

Pros :

Everything is here (exept for the cons) and more.

You can even work in your workshop when you possess a monster of that workshop which is a nice feature for me because it increases the sense of being a real creature in your own dungeon (compared to DK2).
You can also use all skills of the workers, even teleports.

Others nice new" features :

- Full detail about workshops/workshop props/creatures to know how they are
recommended:
how well they are working and why (nicely done)
- Huge tech trees ( a lot to unlock and discover )
- A lot of units with no overlap in term of character design and type
- Titans
- peace groups
- Potions
- Sanctuary for potent spells
- Restricted areas for workers
- workshops build boxes for the traps and you can take them yourself to finish the traps"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAt the moment I DO NOT recommend this game. However I see it's potential and over time I can recommend it. There are probably more cons so far than pros. Constant bugs, HUGE fps issues, no save, no multiplayer, only one mission. I know that the developers plan on adding more missions, a save, a multiplayer. However it has been over one year sense initial release of the beta and we still see no improvement BESIDES UI changes and more rooms/creatures. If you are a Dungeon Keeper fan you will love this game however I think you should wait till they properly finish this game. There are so many bugs and fps spikes its ridiculous and game breaking. (not sarcasm). At times every creature including your imps will freeze and do nothing, i tried all i can to get them to move. I picked them up, i slapped them, i controlled them, and they still wouldn't move. Also, once you build a large dungeon and have an army the lag is ridiculous. Even if you can handle skyrim on max settings you will have issues with the frames reaching a max 10 frames if you're lucky. However once you start a game you should have a solid 30 frames or more. Final Verdict: Save your money, get it upon release. To many bugs and problems at the moment.

reviewText:
Short version:
Pros:
-Same voice actor from the original Dungeon Keeper and Keeper 2, Mr. Richard Ridings, who does a great job!
-Looks like a Dungeon Keeper game
-Gameplay generally feels like a Dungeon Keeper game
-Play the bad guy"
-Dig out a dungeon and stock rooms to attract creatures and then attack the enemy
-Torture Chamber is fully operational
-Devs are patching bugs and paying attention to player requests

Cons (at the time of this review):
-Some features are not available yet (sandbox mode & multiplayer)
-Creature path finding can be somewhat haphazard
-Rooms and creatures do not have enough detail about what they do (still calls things "prop x")
-Possession can be difficult to control and once in possession mode no clear explanation about the controls
-Memory Leak? Game tends to slow down a lot over the course of playing and occasionally crashes (devs stated they are looking into solving this problem)

War for the Overworld is a refreshing change in the standard RTS genre given that you build a dungeon and attack the "good guys". As many know
date: WftO is the spiritual successor to Dungeon Keepers 1 and 2. This is the game I have been looking for since finishing DK 1&2 in 2000 (15 years!). I am sincerely happy that EA has allowed Subteranean Games to create this clear clone of the Dungeon Keeper franchise.\n\nDo not get me wrong
recommended: War for the Overworld is not just a facelift for Dungeon Keeper 2. It does have it's own story if you are a plot addict like me. However
hoursPlayed: the look and gameplay feels just like DK2 on the surface
voteText: but is a bit buggy with path finding which I expect will get ironed out. If you have been looking for another Dungeon Keeper look no further and pick this game up since it is what we wished that "Dungeons" was or "Overlord 1&2" were. It is certainly worth the $30 USD (half of what EA would charge if they made it
helpfulPercent: and it would not be as good) even though it does have some flaws as detailed above. I expect that these flaws will be polished away with a bit of time since these devs are extremely devoted to supporting their product and are enthusiasts themselves for the Dungeon Keeper series.\n\nBuyer with a low-end system beware (i.e. less than 8 GB RAM and less than a Quad Core processor running at 2.0 GHz) as this game is somewhat CPU and definitely memory intensive which manifests itself particularly during battles. I know this because I recently had to upgrade my system to run smoothly (I was capped at 3.25GB RAM and it bottlenecked my Quad Core AMD Phenom II @3.2GHz processor). If your system does not meet the minimum requirements
votesHelpful: either upgrade or expect slow downs
votesTotal: stability issues
votesFunny: crashing
commentsCount: and even unplayability during gameplay
column16: and don't downvote simply because your PC cannot handle it (I see this too often).\n\nAll these things being said
column17: I cannot recommend this game enough. WftO is exactly as advertised with regard to being the spiritual successor to DK 1&2. I played this game when it was in early access and enjoyed it then and now even more. This is the only game that I have ever been happy with after purchasing in early access

reviewText:
I'd recommend this if you were a fan of Dungeon Keeper. It's pretty much Dungeon Keeper with more features.

The only problem I have is you get interrupted SO OFTEN to get told what to do. If you are trying to watch Netflix or something while playing, don't bother because it will get talked over by non-notification dialogue ALL THE TIME. Diatrabe after diatrabe. On top of that you will get straight up forced to place certain things in certain places before you are able to use them anywhere else. You are even sometimes forced on a frozen screen while things are happening around you to perform certain actions. I got slid over to a room as I was about to give a dig command and it caused me to accidentally set a dig command on one of my outer walls that I could not undo because I was frozen on the other room until I finished the task.

It's a lot of very forced and heavy handed tutorial style tasks that I would absolutely love if you could turn off, but I'm not holding it against the game because even though I'm 5 missions in and they are still doing it I am really hoping that they knock it off sometime soon.

reviewText:
Now, there's a decent amount of people who have played Dungeon Keeper and Dungeon Keeper 2 who also grabbed this game. I am one of those people. I LOVE the DK franchise.  Anyways, going to try not mentioning DK/DK2 from here on out. Well, until the end, anyway

War for the Overworld is a dungeon building and managing god game.  You create your dungeon, create rooms, get minions, and level them up to get an advantage over your enemies. You create room, traps, use spells and Constructs. Depending on what you like and what your playstyle is, you can use or keep from using certain rooms or minions in sync with your playstyle. Hell, you could go all turtle style on your enemy if you wanted to.

This game also gives you a decent amount of defensive structures you can use, but from your limited resources, you won't be able to spam them all over the map. Which wouldn't be fun in the first place. Imagine a game where the enemy has turrets ALL over the map. Personally I'd just give the person a win and leave the current game. :P

Every game/movie/series has cliché's. This one is no different in that aspect. Lies, deceit, hero(es)/villain(s) gone batshit insane, plot twists, manipulation, 180 degree turn in personality, and so on and so forth. The usual. Though you can still get genuinely surprised by plot twists. Hell, I can see them coming miles away, and still get surprised. Must be the way the plot twists are handled.

This game breathe new life into the dungeon creating and managing-genre, which were severely lacking since the before-mentioned franchise. Which is kinda sad, as this type of genre is very fun.

Now, this game was officially released on the 4th of April, 2015. Personally though, I feel as if this game is kinda still in the just came outta beta" phase

reviewerDisplayName: Oh my god she's not even 3D
reviewText:
Anyone who likes Dungeon Keeper, is more than likely going to love this game. I remember when War for the Overworld had maybe two rooms and one or two creatures, and there really wasn't much to the game. After owning this game for over two years, and coming back to it after it's grown and matured more, and to be honest it has grown and matured a hell of a lot over two years, but it has shown phenomenal promise I'm not sure if the devs are going to call the game finished, it feels great, but doesn't feel 100% finished. I do hope that in the future Mods will be a possibility, as they could do a hell of a lot for this game. I've been playing the Dungeon Keeper series since the first DK game, and this game definitely qualifies as a spiritual successor.

TL;DR best money I have spent on a game that brings back a lot of nostalgia, even down to the voice of your advisor. The only thing the game is missing, is full modding support, if it had that then it would be on a whole different level than Dungeon Keeper.


EDIT: I should add that I do understand the devs decision to pull mod support for now. Unity doesn't make it easy to mod on their engine as you would need to build the mod tools from the ground up. At this time, something like that would more than likely cost more than it's worth.

reviewText: This game has a lot of potential, but in no way it is ready to be released. As much as I love DK series and this being a spiritual successor of it, I absolutely cannot recommend this game to anyone until it is at least playable. I remember playing an earlier release, and I thought that with the newest patches, at least some of the game breaking issues were fixed. On the contrary, new issues have been introduced. This time I cannot scroll left or right, so I have to use the silly WASD to move around the map. Some cutscenes freeze, such as the one about shifting bond in the fifth level and disable scrolling altogether. Have you guys actually tested scrolling? Was this part of your QA items at all??? Shame on you for using paying users as testers where it should have been your job in the first place. At least now textures do not flicker when you reload the game and the gameplay does not come to a grinding halt. Please test your product before releasing it.

reviewText:
This game brings back all the nostalgia from the good old Dungeon Keeper 2.
It's close to release and the developers seems to be very determined to give their customers what they want.

I've done my research and i'm safely putting my faith in Subterranean Games.

BUT, it hasn't been released yet so i need to give you the present news of the game.
There is little content and no finished campaign.
You still have skirmish and a new mode (Survival) that you can enjoy but it isn't enough for 28€ in my opinion.
The gameplay is coming out as fairly finished.
I've encountered one or two crashes and maybe a few glitches but it's nothing that ruins your game completely, just minor obstacles that are easily fixed.
I do hope that i will see more minions, buildings, spells and traps.
Even though i feel that the current situation with your variety of building is enough i do want more.

It may or may not be the way i want it to be but i'm going to recommend it.
I think you should wait until the release of this game and see where it stands though.

But as i said, i have faith in these developers (something that doesn't come easily these days).

EDIT;
The game has finally been released and the full campaign is open.
However, the game still contains alot of bugs and a few unfinished touches.
I'm sad to say that it wasn't ready for release just yet.
They are releasing ALOT of hotfix patches though and that makes me a little happy.
Since the release they've already released about 7 hotfix patches and that's great but it also gives you a perspective of how many bugs there are to be fixed.
These 7 patches fixed alot of bugs but there are still alot more to be done!
I would still recommend that you all wait a month or two to see where the game lies and how smooth the gameplay is.

reviewText:
War for the Overworld is essentially a Dungeon Keeper 2 remake with a heavy emphasis on blitzing your enemy. At this point, I have made it to level 12 and have yet to actually enjoy making a dungeon as the game has kept me locked in with impenetrable rock and busy fending off attackers from minute one.
I tried out skirmish mode in the hope that it would allow for more relaxed dungeon building, but yet again, the AI focused solely on blitzing my dungeon core before I even realized I had to unlock every room in my tool panel before being able to use it.
If you loved Dungeon Keeper 2, and you love blitzing your enemy then this game is for you. If you loved Dungeon Keeper and enjoyed building dungeons, then Dungeons and Dungeons II are more your style but they are still entirely different games.

Pros:
Fairly Evil Narrator
DK2 style

reviewText:
It's not called DK3, but it plays very much like what I'd like a DK3 to be-- rather than some pay-to-win mobile thing-- and there's that voice again, congratulating you on your evil deeds and chiding you for not killing the forces of good rapidly enough.  Welcome back, Keeper...I mean Underlord.

Anyway, I've played thru level 6 under 1.1.6 without any significant issues.  The only thing I noticed offhand was that there is a pretty major pause at the start of some levels before the voice intro starts up.  Speaking of pauses, I want the 'Pause' key or 'P' or something to do a pause-- the esc menu sort of works, but you can't scroll with the esc menu active.

Graphics quality with all the shiny enabled is looking pretty fine, and the performance seems solid-- no problems holding a steady 60FPS at 2560x1440 @ 60Hz resolution.  Wish I could zoom out a little more, though, or perhaps I'd like the UI elements around the edge of the screen to be a little smaller and not take up as much room.

reviewText:
If anyone has played Dungeon Keeper or Dungeon Keeper II and enjoyed it, just get this. It is Dungeon Keeper in everything but name. It feels like it, it sounds like it, it probably smells like it if I could smell it.

Everything in the game looks and feels just as you'd expect it to, and thanks to a Kickstarter stretch goal, Richard Ridings (The Mentor in DK1 and DK2) voices your dungeon announcer in this as well.

Couldn't ask for a better spiritual successor. It scratched that 16 year itch.

Also, the developers are very active in the forums and seem to genuinely care about what the community thinks, respond to questions and take suggestions to heart. Can't ask for better behavior. From what I hear as well, Patch 1.1 was a HUGE improvement over 1.0 and fixed most of the issues people had with the game previously.

As JonTron would say; Ten outta ten, ten outta ten, hundred outta a hundred, best game, best game!

reviewText:
Updated: An even more interesting alternative is actually an early access game called Dwelvers. The developers are amazingly active and immediately responsive to the community, fixing problems and implementing requests.

Dwelvers offers dungeon layers, cave ins and topside action, craftable equipment and all kinds of ♥♥♥♥. It's excellent and on the road to being my definitive choice so far as the DK successor.


Back to WFTO - I do recommend the game as there's some good fun to be had (again) treating this as a DK 2.0 reboot.

Some solid work was put into the game assets. The writing (in large measure) is also well done and they brought in Richard Ridings once again as mentor, and general grumpy evil scolder of things.

This isn't DK3 because that would involve finally breaking out onto the surface. From what I'm seeing that's not going to happen, unless WFTO is expanded - that would be great and all former DK fans would appreciate it.

Unfortunately there's also some (IMO anyway) glaring contrived things, most notably - sand.

Sand is being used to artificially separate enemy assets from the player. You can't claim it, replace it, put down a sheet of steel (or stone, wood, magic or anything else) to create a connection to take over enemy tiles beyond it.

It's downright stupid, frankly. I think the developers may have decided to use this because they didn't want to go to the effort of dealing with (a lot of added) level design complexities and logic where the player can capture (or cross and continue to capture) empire tiles beyond the single sand tiles carefully laid out as this silly barrier.

I'm calling this out because it may seem low priority but it's actually not. Part of the interest for many of DK is taking over every inch of the underworld, one map at a time.

Another issue more toward imposed balance" is mana (and worker) caps. They've done the system in a way explicitly limiting the players ability to create truly massive defensive systems sprawled across the underworld.

There are other things lacking as well.

But
recommended: the game as-is has without question had a lot of work put into it much of which is good quality. Far more than not it is definitely an updated take on the DK series with some things that used to be fun not implemented or allowed at all.\n\nFor long time DK fans it's still worth a romp and visually it looks great. I still have my original DK1 + 2 CD's
hoursPlayed:
bonus packs and maps I made sitting on a NAS. And I've played both as recently as last year on W7. Takes just a little work then the games work perfectly.

For those without DK experience you should go get and play both of them if you really want to understand and appreciate where WFTO is coming from.

It should (or hopefully) be possible to use an editor to change the core campaign maps to eliminate the stupid sand or (even better) change the properties of sand to make sense (claimable).

The DK editor doesn't by default allow saving campaign maps but that's easily gotten around and allowed players to fine tune campaign maps to suit how they wanted to play it
voteText: in every regard.\n\nHopefully the WFTO map editor is at-least as capable. I've no idea

reviewText:
While I generally think this game is a thumbs up, I can't say I am entirely happy with the level of polish... or lack there of.

It truly feels like a sequel or spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper 2, but seems to lack a little of the heart that went into that title. It has a similar sense of humor, but maybe a bit more drab than the old DK franchise. I can see that the devs loved DK and wanted to make this as close to that concept as possible, but in too many places it falls just shy of the potential.

The old Dungeon Keeper games had some bad bugs in them that made them almost inplayable at times and unfortunately this game does follow that same trend as well. That being said, the devs have not given up on this game and appear to be trying to fix, improve, and expand on the game months after it's full release, so here is to hoping this game gets enough love from both players and devs over time.

All said, it does feel like Dungeon Keeper 2.5... I just wish it had felt more like Dungeon Keeper 3. But still a fun game and if you want to try something new or something old that feels new again, give this game a try. Worth a play.

reviewText:
Answer these questions with yes or no to see if it's a game for you:
- Do you like torturing your enemies to recruit them into your own ranks and send them fighting their own brethren?
- Do you think it's appropriate to slap your minions around your dungeon to speed up their work?
- Do you think that itsy bitsy micro piglets are the right way to stop underworld hunger?
- Do you characterize with some kind of higher being, e.g. a god? Loving, caring, just in a twisted kind of way?

If you can answer these with a rightful YES, then go buy the game. If you're a Dungeon Keeper fan this is a must have.

The developers are a quite small team but have delivered a high quality game, even though it is still a bit rough about the edges a few days after the release i'm sure these things will get patched up quickly.

The price may look hefty at first but is ultimately rightful, as the game offers tons of quality content and delivers it in a fun way, especially if you dig the dungeon keeper it is good to be bad" humour. However
date: you may want to wait until the price drops and more content is delivered / patched."

reviewText:
For me this is a game still in development, the ending of the campaign is very confusing, to the point it is either really bad or its a, to be continued.

However, the game is easy (still trying to complete DK 1) and I was able to complete each level up to level 10 first time and the final level. 11 and 12 took many many attempts.

It has the feel of DK series but the humour is not as good. I was playing to 4AM one night and it did not tell me to go to bed or that my imps did an impression of me.

The voice of the narrator is the same but not in the same style. This is not DK 3 but it is a good modern DK style game.

I have only played campaign and felt this was quick to play and the ending needs something doing to it but I enjoyed it. For £14 it was good, full price, no. I am glad I waited for this release than the early access and can say it worked on my laptop and desktop with only a little stuttering on the laptop (Win 8 integrated chip graphics).

Work on the ending lads, I mean complete it, and if it is to be completed by DLC, think about how you will finish it and the cost as at mo, the game at full price.....is not good.

Further, Nice work so far lads, looking forward to your future work.

reviewText:
So, now that WftO has had a few months to cook after its disastrous (and incomplete) launch, what do we have now at version 1.1?

Well, if you're looking for a Dungeon Keeper 3 that actually works this time, WftO is now it.  The game takes the premise of its spirtual ancestor, and expands it with new units, tools, and various other goodies.  Not all of this is for the best, however; many units and tools still feel underdeveloped and underbalanced.  Again, however, WftO now stands out as the best and the brightest of the DK-alikes out there (although, with Dungeons 2 as its only real competitor these days --with maybe KeeperRL as a very distant 3rd -- that's not saying much).

+ Tried and tested Dungeon Keeper gameplay with its own spin.  That's the biggest plus right there.  After many patches, the dev team pretty much nailed what makes the DK formula special.  This single plus pretty much covers up for the game's myriad sins:

- Campaign needs another pass.  One big quibble is the way that new units and tools are dumped willy-nilly on the player, with no warning or explanation, as the campaign progresses.  DK made sure that new stuff was properly introduced -- and necessary! -- at the end of each campaign mission.  WftO doesn't.

- Poor use of all this new and different stuff in the campaign.  You get a lot of different toys and units, but you will not end up using some of them at all in the campaign.  (See: stone bridge).  This may be useful when playing multiplayer, but it's just clutter in the campaign.  Even read a book that cries out for better editing, for elimination of dross and a better focus on what is important?  WtfO needed a better editor, as it were.  There's just too much redundant stuff in it.  DK2 stripped away a lot of DK1's units and tools, as was the better game for it.

- Much more MP focused than the DK games were.  WftO was evidently created by folks who thought DK's MP was the high point of the game, which is arguable.  As a result, you get less of a contemplative, polish your dungeon to a high sheen gameplay in favor of... zerg rushes and click-click-clicky around the map.

- I was wondering if the devs were trolling me when I won" the game.  Abrupt and unrewarding to say the least.  Not as bad
recommended: as an old NES game that just displayed "CONGRATULATIONS" on a black screen
hoursPlayed:
but close.

- I hate timed missions in a game centered on building stuff.  The campaign has a few.

TL;DR: WtfO is close
voteText: but not quite
helpfulPercent: for those who waited patiently over the decades for a DK3.  It's definitely still worth a shot
votesHelpful:
though.



"

reviewText:
A sort of spiritual sequel to the Dungeon Keeper games. The good ones. Very obviously made by fans of those.

When I say 'obviously made by fans', I mean that the route it has taken to grow past the limitations of its ancestors is more like you'd expect from someone who wants more fo the game, not less of it. It adds options. So many options. Like, wow, man, that's a lot of options.

It's on the verge of feeling badly cluttered, but manages to avoid this. Instead, it feels like your dungeon is more fluid and adaptable.

If you liked DK and DK2, you will probably really enjoy this game. If you never played them, then this game will show you why you sometimes hear those older games spoken of fondly.
