reviewText:
TL/DR: 7/10 This game is fun, pays a nice homage to the Dungeon Keeper series, but still has several bugs ranging from minimal to highly frustrating.

Pro Tip: Do not set the Zoom Level in options to be low. This is counter intuitive (atleast ot me)! the higher this value, the more you can zoom out.

PROS:
Very similar to Dungeon Keeper
appox 10 hr campaign
other game modes: skirmish, survivial, multiplayer
Nice economy feature: Each imp and trap reserves a small portion of your mana pool and caps at some percentage. This means you cant have a million imps and traps, instead only a dozen or two of each.
Skirmish mode has about 10 maps ranging from 2 to 4 player and ranging in size by atleast a factor of four.
Nice feature which encourages non-open floor plans; room pieces (like a torture device in a torture chamber) get increased efficiency for each bit of wall within 1 square.
Somewhat akin to Horned Reaper in DK2, there are three creatures which you can summon, but not control, which are at the apex of each skill tree. Unless you are rushing, I havent found them all too useful tbh.
Traps have two modes, which are interchangable by only a mouse click. The modes differ per trap, but are often more complex than just a defense/offense mode.
Additional creature class called beasts, which are summoned by a room (not a portal).

CONS:
Imps often poorly priorotize work, ie. reinforce walls (or do nothing) instead of claiming nearby tiles
No full page map
Creatures are hard to distiguish from one another.
Creature and room tooltips often do not appear when curser remains over them. I feel like the game is missing in game tooltops to better explain many creatures and rooms.
Strange room/trap/spell/potion research tree which is confusing and annoying if you dont have all the room types built yet
Campaign difficulty sways from trivial to really tough with few in a happy medium. Further balacing is needed.
Even after 15+ hours im not totally sure what some of the more advanced rooms do. Certaintly they arent critical for success.
No Bile Demons, or farts.
Not much (if anything) in the way of creature types which hate each other or fight. This differs from DK series where one might omit particular rooms to assure a happy dungeon.
Doors are useless, and two traps in particular, cannon and well of souls, are OP.
Leveled up imps do not have speed or teleport. But, there are new magic imps which work at a faster rate.
Enemies dont die in prison and turn to skeletons, they stay in jail forever. Enemies which die in the torture chamber turn to stupid ghosts which vanish after a short time. They are best used by posessing and then kamazeeing through the other keepers dungeon - but largely useless.
In skirmish, AI often amasses a dungeon and army faster than humanly possible - which can lead to some frustratng early battles

A few QOL improvement ideas:
-There is a nice feature which you can group creatures into a warband and set a rally flag for just them. For example, warband 1 would be selected by clicking CTRL-1 then clicking the minions, and then sent to a rally by clicking 1 then then clicking on the map. I WISH that after clicking 1, before setting the rally point, all the minions in that warband would appear as distinct white dots on the mini map
- You can select all creatures of a type into a warband by CTRL-1 then clicking thier creature type in the HUD rather than each individual one in the dungeon. I WISH I could toggle to automatically add all new creatures of that type which appear in my dungeon (or are converted in torture chamber) to that warband automatically.
- I WISH I could toggle a rooms activity priority to surpass a rally point. For example, set my archive (library) to priority, so that if I use a Rally ALL point, a few inclined creatures would stay back and do research. This would be really nice for research, trap manufacturing and torturing at the very least.

reviewText:
First of all, this game does still have some bugs.  If buggy games bother you a lot, maybe give it another few weeks.  The devs are working hard, and they're making a ton of progress, but they're not quite there yet.

That said, this game is to Dungeon Keeper 2 what DK2 was to DK1.  If you feel (as I do) that DK2 was a drastic improvement over DK1, you're in for a hell of a ride with this game.

So many improvements to what, at it's core, is the same system.  Take traps/doors, for example.  In DK1, they would build whatever they wanted, then you could place it.  Kind-of annoying, since they would produce all the low-level stuff first, so if you wanted, say, a Steel Door, you'd have to wait.  Then, in DK2, you could place a door/trap, then they would get to work on it.  Definitely an improvement, since it didn't waste resources, but if you didn't currently have a place that you knew you wanted a door/trap, your workshop workers would just be slacking off.  In WFTO, they finally solved it.  Workshop workers build generic parts.  When you place doors/trap blueprints, your imps bring those parts to where they need to be, and after enough parts are brought, the door/trap exists.  It doesn't waste anything, and it's perfect.

Everything in the game is like that.  They took a look at the systems in the DK games and said, How can we make this better?"  They've done a remarkable job.  Researching rooms/spells is done through a sort of "skill tree" so you can spend your research points as you wish.  You can fill back in places you don't want dug out; one of my pet peeves with my DK dungeons is when they could be ruined by intruders
date: and now you can fix what they did.  There are all sorts of entirely new systems

reviewText:
I have tried a lot of hopefuls to the dungeon keeper throne over the years. Overlord, Dungeons, Impire; they all had their charms but none were quite what I was hoping for and I REFUSE to buy Dungeon Keeper 2 from EA after they butchered the whole thing. I was really timid about going into this game because I had been disappointed so many times before but I have been greatly impressed by this game, it has filled the hole in my heart.

It's really easy to jump into if you've played other dungeon games, the skill trees are an interesting addition that makes multiplayer matches more dynamic. With the beast den, potions, constructs and rituals it feels like a genuine spiritual successor to those classics.

The one and only complaint I have is the lack of a dragon-like monster. When I was a kid I always loved to craft a dungeon and populate it with like 30 dragons. Huge scaly firebreathing besties make everything better! who knows though, might be added in future DLC or something. XD
...maybe a skin for the Auger, that would work! Now I have to look into modding
Okay I'm just rambling now so I'm gonna cut it here.

In Conclusion: War for the Overworld is awesome and you should play it!

reviewText:
When I first purchased this game I had little hopes of it ever becoming a complete game with a full campaign. Honestly I hadn't even had it installed beyond the point of the first couple weeks.  Recently I have been pleasantly surprised. Not only has the game been given a campaign with a decent story but it did an excellent job leaving us off for further story (which I hope is on its way) Hours of great game play, good story, versatility and control over your dungeons population, a wide varriety of creatures, spells, defenses and rooms. lastly, a mode in which you can personally challenge yourself after you have beaten the story of the current game.

Cons
- Whan your dungeon population starts getting a bit higher the game starts running a touch clunky (my pc specs are pretty decent)

- Units will sometimes get stuck on the edges objects in a room. This does not occur often enough for it to cause any considerable grief.

Fully recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed DK2 in years passed.

reviewText:
It looks like Dungeon Keeper, it sounds like Dungeon Keeper, but it doesn't obey your dark will like Dungeon Keeper.

One of my favorite things of the Dungeon Keeper series was actually building the dungeon, fortifying it, training my host of evil, and THEN attacking with it.

My least favorite thing in War for the Overworld is that it forces you to play the game at its pace, and doesn't allow you to dictate the pace of the game based on your own tactics.  You are often facing a ticking down timer, or faced with an AI opponent that has a fully built dungeon and starting minion compliment that happily bum rushes directly toward you within five minutes of the level loading with no reguard for its own level 1 minions.

This means that for most of the campaign you're distracted from building your dungeon by having to deal with a constant horde of weak pointless minions constantly trying to make a bee line to your dungeon heart.  On most maps, save for the one the game specifically expects you to create them on defenses generally feel pretty worthless as well, not like you'd even have time to build them on later missions anyway since the game just devolves into planting the All Minion/Beast flags down and spamming heal monster as fast as your mana can support.

I also don't like how once the AI has decided it is going to attack you, there is basically nothing else to do except deal with its suicidal tendencies since it somehow always magically has a full host of minions to keep pouring into your territory, no matter how many you seem to kill/capture.  You can't drive them back and take a breather to let your minions sleep, eat, and get back to their tasks like performing rituals, converting prisoners and raising the collected corpses.  Your only choice is to keep an unrelenting drive directly to the dungeon heart even as more enemy minions run their little level 1 legs into your minion ball.

If I'm not mistaken, Dungeon Keeper had a finite minion pool available on each map, and each portal would only allow a limited number of minions through.  When a minion died, it was gone for good and not available to either you, nor your enemies any longer.  This is what made portals matter, prisons, graveyards and torture chambers vital and scavenging pits so annoying.  It also ment you could slap the ever loving ♥♥♥♥ out of worthless creatures and kill them (or sacrifice them in the temple to make something better) so they wouldn't be constantly taking up a slot a better minion could be filling.  This also ment you could win a war of attrition as long as you killed more than you lost.

Still, I don't hate the game.  I just get frustrated with the way it makes you play it.  I wish Steam would introduce stars instead of just a Yes/No.  My feelings on the game aren't that binary.  But I guess at the end of the day I'd still say it is worth a try, as long as you don't go expecting pure Dungeon Keeper out of it.

reviewText:
A spiritual successor to the Dungeon Keeper series, War for the Overworld is everything you could have wanted and more! It does not try and reinvent the wheel, but instead keeps things as similar to the original as possible while adding some of their own (and community’s) great ideas. The initial release had several bugs - some major, many minor - but the team is currently hot fixing like crazy and improving the game immensely every day.

Some people have complained about the state of the game upon release, and although their opinions are not without merit, it should be said that the team that brought you this game is a collection of DK fans. A team who loved the series and wanted to bring the franchise back to life and have worked tireless to do just that. They do not have some large studio behind them – just us, the community. And I actually see that as a good thing, lest we get a horrid game like the Dungeon Keeper mobile game that EA released!

If you were a fan of DK then this game will satiate that burning desire to imprison heros before you torture them to death, slay princes and their kin, mine gold to stuff your coffers, and recruit evil creatures to your dungeon all in an effort to rule the Overworld!

Richard Ridings: “It's great to have you back….Keeper.”

reviewText:
Ok,Ok, let's get a couple of things straight. First of all i have heard that this spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper,however I wasn't even born then;but i am a huge fan of management games and the RTS genre so i hope this review is unbiased with no nostalgia influencing the review.

So what are the good points of this game?

-Lots of content including spells,defences, rooms and so much more!
-Great graphics
-Chilling voice acting, mainly in the campaign
-Minions are interesting with a good variety of abilities and character models
-Huge tech tree
-A variety of maps in the campaign
-A variety of missions in the campaign

Ok, now for the cons

-Buggy as hell
-Pathfinding is stupid. Oh im sorry minion, walk through the ♥♥♥♥ing enemy dungeon to mine out one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wall
-Oops, got a bit angry there... possession spell is poorly done
-campaign is just one big tutorial
-No maps what so ever outside of the campaign. (Make one where it is just large with no stone Mr Mod-maker)
-Feels unfished
-No multiplayer... really...soz 'ard I can't 1v1 u m9 wiv ma MLG rallie flagz.
-overpriced for what you get.

So in conclusion, War for the Overworld is unfinished, i would recommend it in the future when it is properly patched, but in it's current state i would not buy it unless it is on sale or you really, really want it. However it shows promise and could be 10/10 IGN when PROPERLY FINISHED!!!

reviewText:
An enjoyable spiritual successor marred by bad performance issues.

I have a system with a GTX980, i7-4790K, 16GB of RAM and I have this game installed on an SSD. On the later campaign maps my FPS drops to 16-30FPS depending on my zoom level, changing the graphical settings does nothing but even if it did it still wouldn't be excusable. I get a better frame rate on Witcher 3 with most of the settings cranked up to max for goodness sake.

I'd absolutely love to recommend this game but if I'm having these sorts of issues with a system such as mine I dread to think how this game runs on less beefy systems because even my fully expanded Pet Dungeon is averaging out at 20 FPS.

Here's a quick list of things that stuck to me after playing the whole campaign in one sitting:

The good news?
- It's practically Dungeon Keeper 3, if you've played the previous games playing this will be like riding a bike.
- Richard Ridings is as good as ever.
- They absolutely nailed the sound design.

The so-so?
- Greater degree of micromanagement:
- I really don't like how doors function in this game, there's no 'only open for my minions mode'. You either keep it open or lock yourself in.
- Prisons offer a greater variety of choices but it's always a manual process as to what you do with them. If the developer insists on these not automatically turning into undead like before there should at least be a means to auto-allocate them to the torture chamber, crypt or turn them into gold.
- Imps and traps are tied to a limited mana pool, ultimately limiting the number you can have of either but this also means too many imps affects the number of traps you can create and vise versa. Not only that, imps don't seem to get any sort of speed increase as they level up.

The uh-oh?
- Aforementioned performance issues.
- Campaign is seriously lacking variety. Albeit, there are some call-backs to the sort of thing you'd see in DK1&2 but there isn't much of a sense of exploration and it's sorely lacking in surprises. You won't be running into ball traps or neutral rooms in this game. The maps also often feel a little cramped in regards to how much space they're offering you to build rooms of an acceptable size of quantity.
- Unit balance seems all over the place and level 10 units feel weak. Battles seem to be about whoever has the most amount of units regardless of level.
- And then there's some somewhat niggling issues like your minions getting upset and leaving a fight (or ignoring NPCs altogether) because they want to get fed or paid. I was warned that my minions were starting to revolt on the final level simply because there was such a prolonged period of fighting before you were granted the opportunity to send your minions back home.

I really like this game and want to see it become the DK3 everyone wanted but it still needs some serious work. I certainly don't regret my purchase but these shortcoming need to be noted. If you really want your Dungeon Keeper fix but already played DK1 and 2 to death you still might get some enjoyment out of this. The core is all there, it's all the ragged edges that need smoothing out.

reviewText:
I have waited with playing till major patch and version 1.1.15 out now in July, as an all time DKeeper/Theme Hospital player, what can I say after 5 levels of playing:

- fruitful successor of DKeeper/Theme Hospital/Evil Genius games for both old fans and new people who likes strategic/management games
- very nice up to date graphics, visual and audio effects - very atmospheric game - you will feel the decay and staleness of damp hallways as much as coziness of warm fireplace within your tavern
- I have found no glitches, placehgolders or errors, game is stable and much less resource hungry than 2 months ago
- cant stop playing, as the campaing is damn catchy - turtle/haste as you wish, spend half an hour with researching every single map corner or start fighting right from beginning...
- next iteration of Dungeon Keeper as it should be - all those old good things with more options due to new potions, rituals, wall replacemets,...

CHECK FOR YOURSELF, youre not gonna be disappointed!

reviewText:
This game gets a thumbs up from me. It's the closest thing to a Dungeon Keeper remake that we can hope for.

I do miss the old creatures and heroes from Dungeon Keeper. I don't know why but I prefer generic and recognizable monsters like goblins, trolls, and hero parties with the likes of knights, wizards and elves. In this game you have units with similar roles but different names and skins (Gnarling = Goblin, for example). The result is a bit of a weird exotic mix of creatures and heroes made up by the dev team. I suspect that this has something to do with copy right issues which make too many similarities with Dungeon Keeper a legal risk. I hope maybe one day there will be a mod with some of the creatures from the old games.

Though I'm not a fan of the unit and hero roster I did notice and greatly appreciate that units that you corrupt (convert via torture chamber) actually change their appearance and dialogue. Dungeon Keeper did not give me that.

The gameplay itself is honestly an improvement over Dungeon Keeper 2, and that is high praise indeed! Your minions are much more logically classified as either beasts" or "intelligent". So no more facepalm when I see animals drinking at tables or gambling away money... Only intelligent creatures get gold payments and can do research for example. On the other hand beasts eat much more food and require different approaches to training and separate lairs.
I also like the addition of an alchemy room for potion making
date:
but I'm sad to see no equivalent for the dark temple or my favorite: the graveyard.

There are also some very neat additions. One of the biggest frustrations I had with the original dungeon keeper games was that they didn't let me fill in areas with dirt. In this game you can for a little bit of gold.

Overall I'd recommend this game!"

reviewText:
War for the Overworld is quite obviously the true successor to Dungeon Keeper 2.
War for the Overworld perfectly captures the feel of Dungeon Keeper as well as standing up on its own, regardless of the clear ties to the classic title. It feels good, it plays good, it is good. AI is balanced and provides a genuine challenge. Story Mode expertly blends compelling gameplay with teaching you the game step by step. At the time of writing, I haven't personally tried multiplayer, but if it is as good as the rest of the game, it's good.

I don't know what else to say. With EA being, well, EA with the original series, this is your next best thing. And it is an excellent second option.

Plus the announcer for both Dungeon Keepers is the same for this.

A masterpiece. 10/10 Asmodeus sent me an inbox.

reviewText: I have not had the time to play the game a whole lot yet.  What I have seen so far I really like.  I have played all the Dungeon Keeper games of old.  I do miss ol'Horny and the mistresses.  I realize that they can't do those for legal reasons, but it sure would be great.  I also miss the cut scenes from the original that came up between the scenerios. They were hilarious and gave the old games great charm.  But back to this one.  It is well worth your time and effort.  You can tell these guys actually care about the old Dungeon Keeper games.  I for one think they have done a great job so far.  Are there things that could be added  -- sure.  Are there things missing -- sure.  You have to not only give them time, but they also have a staff to pay.  Great games are not free and this one was started on a shoe string and has been done about as well as could be.\n\nI recomend this game for anyone that likes RTS's with a twist.  And for all those DK fans out there -- This one IS WORTH it.

reviewText:
I purchased War for the Overworld Underlord Edition + Early Adopter Bonus (Early Access) on 22/08/2014.
I put off playing until this month as I wanted to support the development and wait for a more polished" game.
Following is my review of my experience playing from start to finish (Avoiding spoilers and game play guides).

I have been building
date:
customizing and using personal computers and consoles since the late 80s.

My system is:
AMD FX 9370 Eight-Core Processor @4.7GHz
32GB PC2200 RAM
Samsung 850 EVO 250GB SSD
Western Digital Black 2TB
PowerColor R9 290 4GB GFX Card
Running x64 Windows 8.1 Enterprise

Starting the game I found loading times to be a bit long.
Once starting to play the experience was good.
Each level progression was as to be expected and offered a more robust enemy
hoursPlayed:
each level up to and including level 11 took no more than two attempts to finish.
The hardest level from my experience was level 12. I took sometime to complete this level with at least five attempts being racked up.

The final level was very easy. In fact too easy. The only reason I took more than three attempts to complete it was due to a bug that stopped me. This bug persisted through game save and load and system restart forcing me to start the level over on two occasions.

The ending was disappointing. Leaving me
voteText: and others
helpfulPercent:
to think the end cut scene was glitched. (I no longer believe this is the case).

Bad:
Loading times are long
votesHelpful: especially when launching the game I often had "Program not responding" dialogs pop up. After clicking wait for program to respond the game would start.\n\nLag
votesTotal:
Lag and more Lag! The game lags a lot. Especially when big battles are happening.

Still buggy in parts. Even though the game is now considered a "Release" product.

AI can be very stupid. Good for us trying to beat it. No so good for over all game enjoyment.

Sometimes mid battle you are healing or zapping trying to protect your core and.... ARRRRR.... A cut scene as a new minion enters your dungeon with no way to skip the bloody thing.


Good:
As a fan of the Dungeon Keeper games and having spent many
votesFunny:
many hours playing them this game does not disappoint and keeps to the spirit of the DK sieris.

Despite all of the "Bad" above the game is still well worth buying as I am sure with refinement via patches this will fix most of the issues.

Bottom line:
I would recommend this game if you are a fan of the DK games or if you are new.
I score this game 7/10. (This is because I am a fan of the DK games and can over look the issues I had).

I hope the issues are patched and if/when they are the game will be much better."

reviewText:
One campaign, a look through the level editor and a rapid check of the multiplayer later, can I truly give this game a honest review ? Oberon help me, let's do this.

WFTO is a labour of love, a game that was born from passion rather than a desire for money.It is the kind of experience that might be less polished than other games (the game could use a ton of bugfixes), but every inch of the game has been crafted with passion, and you've got to respect that. But there's a lot to say about this spiritual sequel to Dungeon Keeper.

Graphically, the game is superb, and more importantly, it's memorable ! From the colorful rooms, to the dark creatures, down to the little details like the awesome logo (can't keep my eyes off that logo, it's pretty !) or the achievement icons, this games looks great. Kudos to the art team.

Musically there isn't much to discuss, the music is very discrete, but the sound design and narrator voice more than make up for that silence. Too bad after 20 hours all I wanted was for him to shut up, because he never stops talking.

Campaign is solid, a good tutorial that suffers from some ridiculous difficulty spikes at times. I rage quit some missions multiple times because some rival underlord's actions are very random and they won't behave the same way every time.

In the end, this game could potentially become a worthy successor to DK/DK2, but it still needs some fine tuning and polishing. In terms of content, there's more than enough to keep you busy for months, but I don't really feel compelled to return now that i have finished the campaign (which is still something only 10% of the playerbase has done, so hurray !).

Wait for the developers to iron out most problems, wait for it to go on sale, and grab yourself a copy of War for the Overworld.

reviewText:
Review date 2016/01/03, version 1.3, Win OS, only 36 hours under the belt. DK fanboy. 7/10 if they fix the stuttering.

It really does feel like you're playing Dungeon Keeper. It has a somewhat more serious tone than the originals, whether or not that's a good thing will be personal preference.They're apparently already working on patch 1.4. There are few issues  as far as I can see that would negatively affect the gameplay - the only one really that got under my skin was the stuttering on the larger maps. Decent graphics & music creates a nice atmosphere. The game is more fast paced than DK2 - I'd recommend setting the game speed to about 60-70%

My single player experience : The first half has a distinct DK1 feel to it, while later on with the bigger maps it plays more like DK2.  The campaign was a little short for my liking but I would happily buy an expansion to extend that playtime. Some levels are pretty challenging while others are too easy.

Minions : A lot of people didn't like that you had so many human" minions in DK2 and I feel they have a nice balance here. When you upgrade your beast lair and build a fighting pit
date: you get 4 different types plus beastmasters who whip them all the way to the pit so they fight each other for xp
recommended: the beastmaster also gets xp from this. You have 2 rally flags
hoursPlayed: one for beasts and one for all your minions so you can use your beasts to ward of small groups without interrupting your minions. Beasts don't collect wages
voteText: just the beast master.\n\nUndead : Personally I like the way they handled it. Vampires are created by making 3 sacrifices and having a ritual charged. They eat live prisoners. Corpses from the battlefield
helpfulPercent:
torture chamber & prison (after a vampire feeds or they they lie there too long because the prison is full) are taken to the crypt where your necromancers raise them as ghouls (skeletons) who then permanently follow the necro that raised them. Prisoners eat the rats and will not die in your prison.

Potions : A new feature where at the cost of some gold you create potions to be used similar to spells. Build an alchemy lab to attract crackpots who will brew them for you.

Another absolutely great new feature is the ability to create dirt blocks. In DK2 I'd often lose an hour of play because some dwarf decided to tunnel into my dungeon and I would restart the level. How I wish this was a feature in DK2."

reviewText: Good, modernized version of Dungeon Keeper. The game has some flaws and is badly optimized, which can result in bad performance even on newer system configurations. The campaign is a good introduction into the game mechanics and often missions can be done in many different ways. The missions later on in the game will often appear undoable at first but once you understand what mechanic or concept the devs tried to teach in that mission/lesson, it will become a lot easier (good work on that). The campaign is a little short however and the story is generic at best. Great voice acting on the advisor which in my opinion is often a little too serious.\nYou can tell that the devs have tried to trim the game for competitive multiplayer, which is why the game feels a lot more hectic and microintensive than DK. Unfortunately it is hard to find a multiplayer match, due to the lack of players.

reviewText:
I always wished for a sequel to the Dungeon Keeper series.
Now I hoped to have found it.

In itself it is very similar to the Dungeon Keeper games.
Yet I either was wearing my nostalgia glasses, or this game is lacking the certain something.

I cannot quite put my finger on it, but War for the Overworld did not really tie me to the computer like DK used to.


Forgetting DK War f.t. Overworld surely is a decent game.
It might be confusing to get into, but that is no problem if you play the campaign and stuff first.

All in all I can say:
If you came here looking for a DK sequel, go and try the game out. After all you can refund it.

If you stumbled across it without knowing Dungeon Keeper, you found a well made strategy game that keeps unfolding itself more and more the bigger your dungeon becomes.

reviewText:
As a longtime fan of Bullfrog's Dungeon Keeper series, I came into WFTO with lofty expectations. It's for this reason that I feel it would be impossible for me to write an unbiased review of the game based entirely upon its own merits, so I'm not going to try.

This *is* Dungeon Keeper 3; and thus far, it has satisfied or exceeded my expectations on every level.

If you're like me and you've been waiting for all the bugs and nasty bits to be hammered out before you spend your money, the time has come. With the release of the Gold Rush patch and DLC, the game is technically solid, artistically inspired, full of content, brimming with devious personality, and one hell of a good time for god-game enthusiasts.

reviewText: Haven't tried this game til now cause of the numerous bugs reported by users initially. Im an old DK1 and DK2 (in lesser degree) fan of all times. Played for a little more than 3 hours and it really feels like the DK3 we deserve. Every mission takes a full hour if you venture to seek all the secrets it holds, and fully level up your creatures.\nIt seems a bit easier than the original DK1, but i was way younger then and it might be just that. Though i haven't played the new campaign, it feels great to see the developers are continually trying to get new content to the base game since this game was (in my point of view) intented to be played solo, like the original.

reviewText: One of the few game based Kickstarter projects I've backed and which have delivered. WFTO is an enjoyable game, with great audio and visual's, and is a worthy spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper. With caveats.\n\nDK2 remains one of my favourite games, but WFTO can't quite match it. With DK2, I am content to spend a very long time building a dungeon, training my forces and then annihilating my foes. WFTO on the other hand wants you to speedrun the levels as fast as possible. Combine that with some really poor performance problems, I ended up shelving the game for a very long time, only picking it up again recently to finish it off. (Also, as a sideeffect of being forced to rush" levels
date: the game feels bloody short).\n\nAs a Kickstarter backer
recommended: one of the perks I received was a custom dungeon skin - I have never even seen this as it doesn't apply for the main campain. Assumably then it applies to multiplayer (which I'm unlikely to play) or sandbox
hoursPlayed: which I'm likely to try once or twice. Plus
voteText: the game offers bonus skins for unlocking speedrun achivements. Not that I have done these
helpfulPercent: but again I don't see the point of custom skins if you can only use them in limited places.\n\nThat's all my opinion

reviewText: The game is pretty good, I really recommend it. Because the game has like alot of features, and once you complete Campaign, you can also play with bots in skrimish mode, or go to sandbox to play some certain developer-made scenarios and maps with no objectives. Play with your friends or other people in multiplayer, and dominate them with your Dungeon core skills. And play survival mode which is still a prototype. This game is really good. The only problem I have with this game is the AI, if your aren't ust to strategy games, you'll have lots of issues with the AI, but when you've been playing strategy games and other type of games that are similar will have entertained for hours, days and even months. Overall, this game is fantastic!

reviewText:
I really like this game.  It's more complicated than Dungeon II which I also really like.  I do feel that the tutorial in Dungeon II campaign is better though because it explains each little item as you go.  War for the Overworld does not do this.  For instance on Level 7 you really need to build the bombard traps and lots of them but the game does not teach you that you need foundries to get toolboxes to build defenses.  I had a lot of defenses but none of them were building so I had to watch a video online and not only did it show me that you need foundries but that you can pick up toolboxes and put them directly on the defenses to speed up their building.  The game also did not teach me how to use the screen that lists all your monsters and click on it to pick up guys.  I learned that from watching a youtube video.  On level 7 I found the lack of gold to be my biggest obstacle but using blood money and a big prison and turning all their guys into gold statues did the trick.  Infinite gold basically.  Actually it might be level 9 where you have the gold problems looking at my notes.

One problem I have with the game is that moving around on the screen does not work well with the mouse.  In Dungeons II the mouse moves around on the screen really well but in War for the Overworld you really need to use the arrow keys instead.  It works really well with the arrow keys.  Another problem is the game is a bit dark and so it's harder to see the screen.  I understand underground is supposed to be dark but I would really appreciate a little more light for visibility.  Overall the game does a really good job in that you have many minion choices from Succubus to Vampire , etc.

I guess I should be writing this review from the perspective of advertising to someone who has never played a game like this before.  In that case you build a dungeon to defeat the do gooders that come to destroy your dungeon.  You do this by carving out rooms in the underground and then putting things in them like vaults to store gold, Barracks to attract    low level monsters, Prisons to put enemies in, torture chambers for Succubi to convert them to your side or turn them into Ghosts, Beast chambers to attract beasts, etc.  Then you build an army out of these creatures to attack your enemies.  You can also use traps and doors to slow down the enemy or kill them.  All in all this is a very good game.

reviewText: This game has come a long way in the years since I played the original early access alpha. I replayed the game a few times as it was updated to get a feel for how it was progressing, and I must say I am quite impressed with the state the game is in now compared with just 6 months ago. The game is well balanced and the progression is smooth from start to finish on the campaign (and in a skirmish). It's not just feature complete but feature rich.... way more content than ANY Dungeon Keeper game ever made. And from what I understand they have plans to add even more content soon with no signs of stopping! It's almost kind of ridiculous how much work has been put into this game. The personality of the original Dungeon Keeper games is intact and further refined. This game makes me laugh out loud regularly! If you were a fan of the original Dungeon Keeper games, this game could become an obsession for you. HIGHLY HIGHLY RECCOMEND!

reviewText:
Needs alot more polish, but as far as features goes, this game has it in spades! I'm confident this game will shine when the devs have put some more effort into it. It was released to early, but this game feels like a passion project, and that is why I believe it will eventually get to a state where it is a must have for any Dungeon Keeper fan. Every problem this game has is fixable, and beneath the bugs is a faithful spiritual successor.

Pro: - Loads of features
- Great looking
- Good sound assets
- Dark humor
- A developer that cares about the community and the game

Cons: - Too many bugs at this stage
- Missing tooltips
- No Bile Demons or Horned Reaper ;)

reviewText:
Warning: Long personal opinion review ahead.

TL:DR version: As someone who was introduced to PC gaming through Dungeon Keeper 1. I love it, It's great for those nostalgic for the classic Dungeon Keeper" gameplay and a fair introduction to those new to the Dungeon Management RTS genre. Only negative i have is in the games on/off freezing times when alot is happening at once such as a large scale combat.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For those of you who were very upset over EA games mobile abomination and black mark against a beloved PC cult classic "Dungeon Keeper"
date:
War of the Overworld is in my regards a true to form successor that delivered what it's Kickstarter set out to do 2 years ago.

Players who have played or are still playing Dungeon Keeper 1/2 you will find that this game will make you feel right at home as nothing has really changed in terms of theme and gameplay with the only a few small exceptions in regards to the naming of creatures and rooms.

At this time I have only played the campaign and sandbox mode so I do not know what the online multiplayer or skirmish modes are like. But as far as the campaign goes it is a trip through nostalgia lane. As you play through the campaign you find that not only do you play the standard "Build
hoursPlayed: Defend" gamestyle Dungeon keeper made famous.  You also have to play different play styles in order to accomplish your mission goals or to respond to the mission's situation
voteText:
This can provide you with a very refreshing or frustrating challenge depending on how view it. To me the very icing on this cake is that your in-game mentor "The Overlord" is voiced by Dungeon Keeper's very own Richard Ridings who delivers the same grand performance he made in Dungeon Keeper while also providing the games comic releif in the lines he delivers during gameplay.

Sandbox mode is essentially DK's "My Pet Dungeon" where you are given all and unlimited resources to allow you to build your very own perfect dungeon with out any worry of being invaded or having to accomplish some mission. I think it's a bit dull but it's something to do in your downtime all and all.

Now while I have praised the game alot so far and I still recommend it to those interested
helpfulPercent: There is one negative I have in that the game will slow down to a stand still if there is alot going on at once
votesHelpful: This happened to me multiple times on one mission in the campaign where there are 3 different teams all with large sized armies. There was so much going on it would freeze the game up for a minute or 2 and my PC has been setup to run most of the latest games on high graphics
votesTotal: So far the game has not crashed but I do recommend saving your progress every now and then."

reviewText: This game is a great follow up to the dungeon keeper series! Lots of new features and creatures, many things to like about it... However, this is most certainly a not quite ripe yet situation. I think as long as the devs keep regularly fixing and improving the game (ala Keen Software House) this game will be amazing. Short of that it will be another tragic effort to reproduce the game we all remember and love. I picked it up to support them in there effort and even in it's current status it's good fun. This has a lot of potential and i am looking forward to it being more polished. Buy now to support them, buy later if you want a fully finished game.

reviewText:
For anyone who remembers at the end of Dungeons Keeper 2 watching the Reaper going out in the overworld at the end of the campaign and still sheds a tear thinking about it and those glorious days.... Look no forward! After few not really worth ideal successors here is a game that takes exactly where the gone Bullfrog left and improves it adding many more features and diversifying your arsenal. I'm just at the beginning of the game but I had to stop because tears of nostalgia were blinding me.
I've finished the first few missions that introduce you to the game: you are a dungeon lord that explores a subterranean world and attracts minions and terrible creatures to work in his dungeon to search for new powerful spells or build traps and doors to protect your dungeon from rival keepers or from those awfully pretend-to-be-heroes that wants to stop you from recovering your realm.
Didn't try multiplayer yet and many other features that are available other than the single campaign, but I love more the solo options, so my review even when updated in future, will reflect this.
At the moment I can say I am really impressed by this game I followed through updates from the beginning of the early access and I was really waiting to install it (bought long time ago and never played as my library is quite full...).
To all Dungeon Keepers fan: do not hesitate! Just remember to keep your social life alive.
To all other younger players: it's a funny and easy to handle game, it's worth more than a try.

reviewText:
For anyone that is a fan of the Dungeon Keeper series, this is a wonderful spiritual successor. Been playing for a long time, and they've come such a long way since early access.

It plays, feels, and sounds just what I would expect a DK game to be like now. Lots of new rooms, abilities, spells, creatures - everything.

There's still some slight bugginess (as of 12/16/2015) - mainly just some minor issues with the GUI (IE: if you slap a minion too fast, it will only show the animation for the first slap)

Campaign is a lot of fun. It's well designed. I'm about halfway through it.

I'd highly recommend this game if you're looking for a Dungeon Keeper fix.

reviewText:
Although I haven't played all that much of this game yet, due to being overly addicted to Don't Starve, I still have adored the parts that I have played. This game is blatantly the remastered version of the Dungeon Keeper series (which is an awesome franchise). You start as a newly awoken 'Underlord' (They didn't want to rip off the Overlord series). As the dungeon master, you must build and slaughter your way through the underground realms, to take over the surface.
I may add more to this review once I have played more of it, but the only problem I have is the difficulty. Even in the early game, the gameplay is brutal.
If you're new to the Dungeon Keeper games, I expect you will struggle a lot.
Apart from that, get this game, you will (probably) not be disappointed.

Highly recommended - 8.5/10

reviewText:
Overall Rating = 8.5/10

This game will remind you of Dungeon Keeper almost immediately, and does a good job of keeping things fun and interesting, but it does need more content and polishing.  However, it is still worth the purchase right now, and I'm convinced the development team is dedicated to improving the gameplay and world, especially after reading their state of the game updates.  Give these guys a chance, they really get it" and aim to please all dungeon keepers out there.  I mean... underlords! :)

What really needs improvement?

reviewText:
Good enough to warrant a purchase.  But up there with Dungeon Keeper 2?  Not quite.

Playing War For The Overworld has been an enjoyable expierence, but one that hasn't quite brought the same thrilling gameplay, presentation or atmosphere of Dungeon Keeper 2 (the game that it is trying to follow on from).

Most of the original gameplay elements in DK2 are intact, along with some fresh ideas.  For the most part it is well executed, too.

Unfortunately, fans of Dungeon Keeper/Dungeon Keeper 2 are likely to have very, very high expectations since both are a very formidable act to follow.  And here, War For The Overworld falls a little short.

Specifically, short in the following areas:

* Richard Ridings' voice makes a welcome return, but his scripts seem to lack the originality and humour of his earlier narrations.

* Similarly the environments, rooms and characters, while well-polished and detailed, are a little lacking in character and are for the most part forgettable. Voices other than those of Ridings' are... a little cringeworthy.

* AI attacks (campaign) feel very much scripted.  I know that they always will be, but the problem is how much they FEEL so. It affects suspension of disbelief, and I get the impression that most of the time my Dungeon creation is periphary compared to how much I can electrocute enemies, heal minions and drop minions at critical locations.

* Some poor optimisation (game at times becomes very stuttery when busy, even on high-end hardware) and bugs (stuck in walls when posessing a minion - clipping bug?).

* The music is largely forgettable, in comparison to Dungeon Keeper 2's, which had wonderfully atmospheric gregorian chants.  I think the music's contribution in DK2 is mistakenly underestimated, and once again is a very tough act to follow.

I don't want to beat up on this game though, and I've had some fun playing it.  Given the amount of commitment the devs have shown, I hope they'll continue to improve things.  I look forward to having another play some time in the future.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of the original Dungeon Keeper series, I was estatic when I learned about War for the Overworld. The developers made some hefty claims, but they delivered. From hiring the original voice narrator, to the look and feel of the game, this game is spot on. The minions have a lot of character, although some are sorely missed (I'm looking at you Mistress and Horny), the updated gameplay and smooth controls more than makes up for it.

For anyone considering this game, if you have a sense of humor, and enjoy any combination of stragegy, god-sim, or slapping imps, this game is definitely for you.

A+

reviewText:
For those who loved Dungeon Keeper, this game is for you. There are a few bugs to be worked out... and I believe the game probably should have stayed in Beta for a few months longer to work them out. It's small things really, information about units/tiles which isn't fully there, no capability for more than 2+ opponents in multiplayer/skirmish and the odd random crash due to things I'm not even sure of. These however are being worked on by the Dev's from what I can read.

But the game itself is still pretty good regardless of all that I've mentioned. A plethora of minions, the voice over/game tutor with attitude, the spells and good use of the Unity engine presents the game in a very graphically pleasing way. It's a very worthy spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper that's for sure... and if like myself you still have a bad taste in your mouth from EA's attempt to milk money from the name, this should help wash it away.

I'd be lying though if I would call this a complete game". As I said earlier
date: it probably could've done with staying in Beta a little while longer and I have a feeling you'll feel the same if you buy this game now. That being said I would still recommend it
recommended: it is very deserving of your money
hoursPlayed: but be prepared to ignore a few incomplete aspects of the game."

reviewText:
Impatient, non-readers can scroll to end for TL,DR


I jumped on this bandwagon about two years ago. I was excited about what they were doing and hoped beyond hope for a game that truly was more Dungeon Keeper. I participated in their discussions and made suggestions. I watched their videos and read their reports. I was all about this game... For about 6 months.

In the following months, I became very bored with this game, I admit. I actually felt that things were rolling out too slowly and was concerned that I had bought in to yet another early access" game that would actually be "forever alpha access" instead. About a year ago I uninstalled the game and moved on
date: chalking this up to another learning experience.\n\nYesterday
recommended:
I noticed it's full release. I have no idea why I went to their page and ultimately installed the game to try playing it again (I really had given up on it) but I guess I was bored enough? I braced myself for disappointment.

I think that having so many other early access disappointments really made me far too over-harsh on this group and what they were doing. I was giggling in the first mission and I was hooked in the second. This game is exactly what they said it would be. It's DK without major publisher taint all over it. It's DK's successor.

Is it perfect? Nope. No game can be. Is it broken? Nope. Everything is playable and fun. Is there a learning curve? Yep. But if you played DK
hoursPlayed: you have completed the basic tutorial. Are there bugs? Yes. And the team is already all up in that.\nI don't approve of people giving this game poor reviews due to the multiplayer not being in full function (at time of writing) or because their system can't handle it (I have a decent system at best and have had very little lag when my dungeon was huge) because that's not what these reviews should be about in my mind. DK was mostly single player
voteText:
and the single player game is awesome.

My only real complaint (and it is easy to remedy) is the voice acting for minions can be a little repetitive.

Having seen where they started and looking at where they're finishing
helpfulPercent: this game did not fail at it's task. If you miss your DK and the other dungeon manager games have fallen flat
votesHelpful:
then this is what you've been waiting for. You won't be disappointed.




TL
votesTotal:

Go on. Have fun."

reviewText:
Version 1.1.7 review

Its hard to say if i recomend this game, On one hand its a fantastic remake of the dungeon keeper series, The graphics are good, Sound design is good, Levels and story are interesting, Creatures are well designed and it is what I would of wanted from dungeon keeper 3.

The bad points

Terrible frames per second later in-game - PC core i7 & gtx 680 12gb ram - towards the end of the game i get 2-25 fps

Bugs-
Prison's dont work properly my imps get stuck in a endless loop of putting my enemies in prison.
Rituals get stuck and i have to sell the room and rebuild it to make a new ritual.

gamebreaking bugs on last level of campaign - activating kenos" and my minions cant move past the barrier.

Despite this I stil love this game

reviewText:
I was suprised how remnisent this game is of both the Dungeon Keeper games.  These guys did a fantastic job of making a spirit successor to those great games.  Well worth picking up and playing, especially to the cult fans of the original Dungeon Keepers.

It goes much more in-depth than both of them, with some over-the-top units (I just miss horned reaper and bile demon), and the same stupid humor, with the same overlord voice.

You'll love it.  Even if you've never played Dungeon Keeper before, this game is a solid and fun RTS/God game.  Don't expect it to be SC2 material, but it's a lot of fun, even if you're just playing around with friends.

reviewText:
Current Build: v1.0.23

It's Dungeon Keeper with it's own little twists, and it's even voiced by Richard Ridings the original DK mentor.

Full campaign is out now. Multiplayer and Skirmish is still in development state at this time, and we have no current word on when they are more maps and 4 player support.

Survival mode update coming out sometime later this year, which will feature daily challenges and leaderboards.

Expect a little slowdown when fights get massive and when your dungeon gets too luxurious.
However for an early build, I think the optimization is pretty spot on.

Give them time to work out the kinks. This is the game Dungeon Keeper fans have been waiting for.
You will not be disappointed if you played the originals.

reviewText: Fantastic follow-up to Dungeon Keeper 2 with the same style and charm with just enough new stuff thrown in there to make it worth your while. The game is buggier than it should be at launch, I'll admit, and some stuff just feels a little rough, animations, some of the options, but it's also a hell of a lot of fun for anyone who enjoyed Dungeon Keeper 2 and was looking for a game to follow in its footsteps. If you're hesistant, it may be best to wait for some patches, but the developers are very vocal on the fourms and the entire development process has been so transparent I would have no problems recommending this game even in its current state. It's certainly playable, and the plans for future content are exciting.

reviewText:
I'm trying my hardest to have fun here but it just doesn't have the same magic as the originals did, which I played immeditely before starting WFTO

They tried to make the narrator humerous like the older games but they seem to have flandarized him and made him more cartoonishly evil than something actually menacing.

The designs of the campaign levels I've played as well as some of the sandbox/skirmish levels felt very restrictive, so I never really felt like I was having fun building the dungeons. In DK2 I felt like I was slowly creeping out and corrupting the land, my dungeon growing organically.

WOTF ends up feeling more like a standard RTS than a base-building/management sim that I liked in Dungeon Keeper. It's not terrible, but it's also not what I was looking for.

reviewText:
I'm a long time player of Dungeon Kepper 1 & 2...and am old enough to remember the thrill of loading these games for the first time.

Although I've been a supporter of this project since they first started, well before when they had a different team and a different goal, the amount of progress these absolutely hardcore lovers of DK have made is quite astonishing.  This game is stonking amazing...it literally is the third coming of Dungeon Keeper.

I've been a backer, but I honestly only played occasionally, feeling that it would be best to play when the game was pretty much feature complete and also since I don't have much time to bugtest it made the best sense for me.  I am absolutely THRILLED at what they've done here...what they have managed to accomplish.

I have played up until the 5th mission in campaign as well as some putzing around in the other modes for several hours (30+), and I can truly say that this has been the time of my life.  The heart and soul of DK is there.  Yes, sure, there's a few bugs and glitches, but this is a massive undertaking that they've done here and the end result is quite simply astonishing.  It looks brilliant, and the humor is there.

I experienced zero crashes and very few bugs on my playthrough today.  I played about 4 hours straight and had an absolute blast.

I've enjoyed checking out every room and looking at the tiniest details in each of their design.  Posession is quite fun and reveals the amount of work put into each of the models and objects.  It's exquisite.

I have absolutely no doubt that given a month or so, a ton of the early bugs will be squashed. This developer team is hardcore committed to making this project a success and you can see it everywhere.

If you're a fan of the original DK, or are looking for a game where it's good to be bad, please check this out.  It is quite simply a load of fun with an immense level of detail that puts other games to shame.  This is truly an incredible job they've done and they deserve a swift pat on the back for what they've accomplished.

Buy it!

reviewText:
This is the first time I've felt compelled to review a game, which hopefully indicates the strength of my conviction. If I  sound harsh, I'm sorry.  I just want to be honest.

In the current form of this game, as of 2:49 AM on April 9th, 2015 I can't recommend it for purchase.

Let me start out by saying something very positive- this game has great potential.

And I do like the graphics, for the most part, and I've had no major issues with the A.I. on both sides...

Okay,
Now my biggest complaint is that the game is simply not finished.  I thought and believed I was purchasing a product ready for use but that is not the case. For instance, playing through the campaign I found numerous placeholders where names of characters should have been marked. I know that might be insignificant in the whole scheme of the game but details matter and this game is just not there where a product should be when brought to the marketplace.  It is not polished, it is not complete, and it is not worth a purchase at this current time.

The campaign felt untested, like I’m a paying beta player and they still expect feedback on the balance of gameplay.  But I’m not a paying beta tester, I’m a disappointed consumer who feels bamboozled.

The game is buggy as all get out (and I've heard they have been working on the situation...and I can forgive a few bugs...but not when the games crashes or freezes over and over.) I must applauded how quick the developers have responded with patches.  This act has given me hope.

The loading screen, which takes forever, reminds me of games dating back to the earlier 2000’s, and not in a good way. Actually, this game feels like an early 2000 release but it isn’t…which makes me sad…because at least then I could have given it a pass for being out dated.  But, that is not the case.

I have read this game is trying to emulate Dungeon Keeper 1 & 2, a game I have not played, so I can’t speak from that point of view. However, as a newcomer to this genre I have felt the uneasy tension that this game doesn’t have a personality of its own. It feels bland, a dime store novel filled with stock everything.  I have not had one single WOW moment during gameplay that inspires me to continue playing or advocating my friends to purchase this game.  It just feels generic.  I loved the idea presented in this game but the execution is lacking.

A few functions of the game I found odd, wait, no, I actually found missing, are common place in many other strategy games I’ve played.  For instance, I have yet to find any indication of a pause button, a min/max speed button, or a restart option on the menu.  Frankly, a restart option would be fantastic because of how many times I’ve had a campaign with unclear directions and a steady stream of escalating forces pushing down on me from the start, killing me off quickly and forcing me through the torturous load screen once more because apparently I’m a glutton for punishment.  Ugh, it’s just bonkers to me that these three options are not presented in the structure of the game.  I digress, for maybe I’m a foolish gamer who has become spoiled on what I thought were considered common place functions built into modern games.

Something must be said about the lost art of creating your dungeon, alas, maybe I assumed too much about the game actually allowing you to create a dungeon to fit your deepest and darkest desires.  More often than not, it comes down to pure function overriding any hope of creating  something to satisfy that hunger of building a dungeon worth calling a dungeon.  I feel the fast, pushy pace of the game doesn’t help, but again, there is no pause button to allow you to form a creation you can be proud of to counter the speed at which the game opperates.

I am also amazed at how fast you can bring down walls.  The sensation of seeing the walls crumble in mere seconds pulls me straight out of the game because I don’t experience the satisfaction of ripping the earth out bit by bit in my endeavor to create something worthy of occupying the space.  To be clear, I’m not saying it should take an hour per wall, but I do feel that the balance is not correct when it comes to the speed of clearing a cavern for your lair and monsters.  I don’t feel like I’m accomplishing anything due to the speed at which this process occurs, especially when I wish to make hallways to connect my rooms and an enemy can come through and burrow through said wall with remarkable ease and speed. I think the economy of the overall game structure doesn’t feel balanced to how I hoped or expected it would be. Did the developers plan on games/matches to occur and finish under ten minutes? If so, then I have chosen poorly with my purchase.

And last, but not least, the mini-map. Really, it feels like it was created in Microsoft paint? It's dreadfully painful to use and basically takes up space in it's current form. Again, if this was a game made in 2001 than I wouldn't be as upset to the design of the mini-map, but it's 2015.

I've read this a small develpement team funded by kick starter and that's all awesome, truly,  however, I don't think that should excuse them from releasing a game in this current form. I get giving them slack where you might not with a larger studio, but at some point that slack runs out and they run the risk of accidently hanging themself...and letting the game die...and I hope that doesn't happen.

Let me end by saying something positive- this game has great potential and I hope that somehow it becomes nurtured and turns into what it could be, a great, fun, challenging game…but until it happens, stay away.

reviewText:
Early Access ReviewBelow is my review of the Early Access build.  Left it here as it seems to be the right thing to do.

Brilliant game, highly recommened if you love Dungeon Keeper, but just as a caution its still in alpha/beta phase so only buy if your willing to cope with bugs and some missing features.  However the game at the moment does have a few sandbox maps to play on, which is always a good thing.

The game is also being constantly updated, and from what I can see they could make this a final release if they wanted, and the developers also coinstantly update their fans every Wednesday.
Final Release reviewBelow you'll find the review of the final version of the game.

Pros+ Plays a lot like Dungeon keeper 2
+ Runs fairly well on lower end hardware
+ Brilliant voice acting
+ Visuals are pretty good
+ Not published by EA
+ No Asset flipping

Cons- Still a few minor bugs and glitches here and there
- Long loading times (This may be my system though)
- A few frame rate issues here and there.

OverallThis is the Dungeon Keeper we wanted.  Something that EA could never provide.  While the game does indeed have its issues and some frame rate problems, it is highly recommended and with the sales coming up soon you might even be able to pick this up really cheap.

At its core its Dungeon Keeper, with a lot more.  After playing a few missions in the campaign I found the game is a lot faster paced than Dungeon Keeper 2, but it isn't bad in fact its quite exciting.

reviewText: I wanted this game to change my opinion of Early Access.  It did not.  Honestly all this game had to do for me to recommend it would be to slap some modern graphics on DK2.  It didn't do that either.  WftO changes the DK formula enough to make it not fun.  There is no developing your creatures and managing your dungeon it is all about rushing the battle and moving to the next level.  Add to that a lack of polish, an unfinished feel, and several bugs and I cannot recommend this game.\n\nIf patches change these issues then I will update this review.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGood Day Underlords! For anyone who grew up playing the Dungeon Keeper games, this is an absolute must, unlike a few other games I've tried that don't live up to the hype at all, this game manages to give the exact feeling that Dungeon Keeper did, this however has far better graphics as you can imagine, and also adds several brand new rooms and monsters. reviewText:
Do you like Dungeon Keeper 2 and you are looking for a successor? Then this game is probably for you.
Are you able to wait for 1 or 2 months? Then you probably should!

This game plays like Dungeon Keeper 2, brought some refreshing ideas of its in into it but right now it still has some bugs and missing features that might worsen your experience. But the team behind WftO is clearly working hard to get rid of these problems and i am sure it won't be long until this game plays the way it is supposed to.

Pro:
+ Dungeon Keeper Feeling
+ Same narrator as in DK2
+ Fresh ideas to this genre (Potions, Tech Trees,...)
+ Developers clearly care for the game and their community
+ it feels good to be bad

Con:
- Some bugs still have not be fixed
- Features like skirmish maps are missing
- NO Dark MIstress

Buggy and slow, other than that shows great promise.

Can't recommend this game even in current version. Go play order Dungeon Keepers and come back 1 year from now, then buy it.

reviewText: I was really looking forward to this game, as a fan of the Dungeon Keeper 2, and held off buying it earlier on because of the bad reviews regarding how buggy it is. In it's current form, it seems quite playable besides the odd bug (I found on the last map, minions couldn't find food or their bed if my dungeon became too large, even despite my attempts to keep the layout simple.)\n\nIn general, I have to say I'm disappointed. Being named War for the Overworld
date:
I expected it to actually follow on from the DK2 storyline and actually be a war for the overworld. However, the campaign just seems like a stale revamp of the original. There's any number of directions it could have been taken in and I was expecting new and exciting content, a new world, new storyline and new characters. The game just seems like DK2 with a new skin though, and little tweaks that just come across as a either a lack of imagination or, more likely, a lazy attempt to avoid copyright violations. If the developers were trying to honor their predecesor, that's one thing, but there just seems to be very little original content added on to what has been copied.

I found the start of the campaign a bit tedious, given that the 'tutorial' is built into it, and I'm sure other old players remember enough of how to play to just want to get straight to the meat of it. Unfortunately there wasn't really any meat at all. The levels were very much in line with those from the previous game and the ending felt very anticlimactic and disappointing. There were no quirky cinematics and even the humour, which the previous game was iconic for, falls short of the mark.

I'm not as much of a fan of PvP as I was in Dk2, and I'm sure if you are, you'll get more out of this game than I did. For those who prefer single player though, don't get your hopes up. The game just doesn't have any replay value as far as I'm concerned. When I finished DK2, I felt like playing the campaign again straight after. With WftO I finished the campaign and just felt like kicking the game into the corner and never looking at it again.

There was also a lot of talk about adding new content to the game, but I haven't seen much at all. There are some new maps to play on but most seem to be coming from the the playerbase and are of course completely disconnected from the storyline. The updates are mainly bug fixes with the odd new (and boring) spell thrown in, and of course character skins (which you have to pay extra for.) The updates are also very slow for what they are.

The one good thing I can say about this game is that the graphics are pretty decent. But given the time between now and when DK2 was released, you'd expect better graphics anyway. However, if you were to offer me this game as it is, or DK2 with updated graphics, I'd rather pay for the latter. No competition.

There's just far too much lacking from this game for it to be labelled a spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper" (according to Wikipedia.) I can appreciate if the developers have a lack of experience in game development or lacked imagination in making this game as a tribute. But what really irritates me is that they seem to be more focused on peddling merchandise than giving players a decent gaming experience. They took a scrapped gaming idea from another company
hoursPlayed: instead opted to copy its predecessor and even failed to do that
voteText: and then took months to release patches to make the game playable because they were probably too busy focusing on their merchandise. It's pure money making by playing off the success of a far better game
votesHelpful: buy it instead. If you have
votesTotal: buy something else that supports developers with more imagination (usually at a lower price too). And if you bought or are planning to buy one of the character statuettes on the WftO store
votesFunny: you need to take a long hard look in the mirror and ask yourself "What the hell is wrong with me?""

reviewText:
Before I post this, I backed the game on Kickstarter and bought it on two separate accounts. I wanted to love this game, I was very enthused about it, I initially gave it positive reviews and decided to wait and give it a chance to be patched.

But now several months in the game lacks a Pet Dungeon mode and the Sandbox Mode is a poor substitute because it has no missions, no objectives, and no real sense of progression. It didn't even have a hero gate on the maps I checked. It seems like a step in the right direction but if nothing more is ever made of it, it's an inadequate half step.

The Campaign initially struck me as promising until I noticed that it's full of pre-fab rooms and rushes you to finish and basically punishes the player for trying to  lovingly hand carve a dungeon.

Aside from that it's not bad, but months after launch I had hoped it would be more of a spiritual successor than it actually is. Dungeons 2 is actually a closer spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper 2 than War for the Overworld is, and it has multiple factions to play as, so if it comes down to a choice between War for the Overworld and Dungeons 2 for DK2 fans I'd suggest buying Dungeons 2 instead.

I'll change my recommendation later if they add a Pet Dungeon equivilent and revise the Campaign maps to be more about crafting a dungeon and less about capturing rooms and rushing, but for now, I give it a thumbs down on the grounds that this isn't as much like Dungeon Keeper 2 as it appears on the surface. Once you dig past the surface, it's a very different game, and a bit of a letdown.

reviewText:
I bought this game in 2013 apparently and since the have not played it while patiently waiting for the developers to finish it.

While they did add a lot of rooms, spells, traps, sounds and a voiceover since then... it still feels unpolished.
Personally i've got several issues that persisted through every version of the game:

1) Cursor is hard to use. Yes, you are reading it right - the cursor. They made it look like a finger from an original game, unfortunately as far as using it in the game it somehow became harder, probably due to increased resolution. Clicking on stuff is mostly hit and miss" situation since the active part of the cursor is just the fingertip. Combine that with the fact that you have to click directly on the stuff
date:
like treasure chests and tiny imps - you've got yourself an annoying issue.

2) Tooltips. Many reviewers already mentioned that they do not make any sense whatsoever and its true - instead of clear information about rooms its just some strings with numbers and abbreviations.

3) UI. There is no way to soften the blow - its horrible in every possible way. The buttons are too small. The cursor is too big and hard to use (read 1). The minimap (again
recommended: made to resemble an original DK minimap) is completely useless and would've been appropriate in the year 95 - Microsoft paint blocks instead of actual rooms and enemies just won't cut in 2015.\n\n4) I've expected that with time and better optimization the game would demand less PC resources but unfortunately the opposite has happened. So just a heads up - you really DO need 6-8gb and more
hoursPlayed: as well as good CPU.\n\nUnfortunately the game has not met my expectations yet (in the basic controls department at least) and i've waited quite a bit already. I might change my mind later on

reviewText:
I wasn't there when the game was first released, but I'm sure the current state of the game is a vast improvement over how it was.
However it still has a way to go. Having spent a couple of hours on the campaign and having done about 5 of the maps this is how I feel about the experience:
Initially I found it very good since so many things of what made Dungeon Keeper great was present and the game does have the potential for greatness.
However I did find things which did chip away at the experience and in the end just made me close down the game and hope it improves before trying it again.

Minor annoyancesYou can't continue playing the map after reaching your goal. So if you have missed a secret you can't go around exploring the map like you might be used to from DK.
Dragging an area for excavation bugs out.
If you try to let go of the mouse button while the mouse is over a gui element (minor annoyance really but it happens so frequently it does disturb the flow" of the game for me).

Major annoyancesHard to visualize what is going on with the minimap.
When you are being attacked I never got the sense that "the minimap will tell me exactly what is going on"
date: but it didn't really because before I knew it my core was being assaulted by a group of mobs.\nThe notification tiles are missable and hard to understand at a glance.\nThe size
recommended: placement and icons for the notifications are just off
hoursPlayed: so I end up never relying on them because they are not in my face when they need to be
voteText:
and when I take a look I can't really figure out what type of message they are. Don't know how many times I thought a minion was starving based on the icon but it was just a new arrival in the dungeon.
Zooming out is pretty limited.
On maps where you take over other NPCs rooms etc you never really get a chance to orientate yourself and figure out where things are since the camera is always sticking pretty close to the ground. Would be nice to get a bit more overview of your dungeon.
Rally minions button is so easy to forget to turn off.
On one map I forgot that I had rallied my minions 20 minutes ago and couldn't figure out why all my minions were complaining about being hungry and wanting to get paid etc.
The only visual feedback you get from it being activated is an extremely small Cancel icon next to the Rally icon turning red instead of grey. And the rally flag itself is pretty easy to miss amid surging minions.
Rally minions makes the minions daft.
The description says that all the minions will fight towards the banner. So if you have a banner placed and then pick up some minions and drop them by your core that is being attacked
helpfulPercent: you would expect them to dispose of the intruders and then walk back to the flag. But that's not the way it seems to work. They just blindly walk back to the flag most of the time
votesHelpful:
even if they run across multiple enemies on the way.
The mouse pointer is hard to target with.
When you hover over a excavatable land the cursor turns into a hand with a pickaxe and for all other elements in the game it becomes a hand with a pointing finger. For some reason this transitioning animation is making it very hard to me to accurately click buttons or select things. My brain gets the impression that the tip of the cursor is closer to the hand. The animation is slow enough that it will be noticeable when you need to do stuff quickly.
Tab hell.
There are a lot of tabs going on in the interface
votesTotal: even though there is a lot of room left when you have a decent resolution.\nThere is the room tab
votesFunny: units tab
commentsCount: spells tab
column16: constructs tab
column17: defenses tab
column18: potions tab and rituals tab (so far anyway
column19: maybe there will be more in the later levels). It is a lot of tab switching and there doesn't seem to be any hotkeys for it either. Given the vast space left at the bottom of the screen it feels like they could utilize the area better to reduce the number of tabs. For example having one area for building (rooms
column20: defenses
column21: constructs) and another for the other stuff. Then at least you have more functionality available on the screen at any given time.\nNo quick way to check the status of your rooms.\nYou can right click on a room in the rooms tab and it will bring you to that room. If you have multiple instances of the same room you click it multiple times. But you don't have a way to view the stats of your rooms
column22: which is very interesting for dungeon management
column23:
so you know when it is time to build a new lair due to lack of space.
Not easy to see why a specific minion is unhappy.
You see a minion run by with a big frown on their icon and you of course want to know why. The information is hidden in the expansive tooltip somewhere but as the minion is still moving it proves to be a mighty task to simultaneously keep following it with the mouse while trying to browse the text in the tooltip (which has A LOT of information).
In general the tooltip is relied upon for way too much and contains the combined lore and stats for whatever you are hovering over which is way too much information when you are in a hurry.
They would benefit much over reducing the information or adding situational information somewhere in the game area instead (like a small chicken next to the frowny face when a minion is hungry
column24:
or a small flag in every room which contains the basic stats for the room you are hovering over)


Many of these things can be argued that they are very trivial
column25: but when it is so many things at once it becomes a draining experience. Many of the things are related to keeping abreast of the situation in your dungeon
column26: which is pretty much what the entire game is about. Then you want these things to be spot on
column27: you should never feel like you don't have the tools to understand what is going on
column28: and being properly notified with huge flashing icons etc when your dungeon core is being attacked etc.\n\nThat being said I do hope it does get an extra coat of polish and refinement
column29: because I have waited very long for a game like this to resurface but as it currently stands I can't really recommend it
column30: though I can recommend that you keep abreast with news about the game in hopes that it will get the polish it deserves in future patches."
