reviewText:
Firstly keep in mind that this game still is an early state of development meaning that there will be bugs and issue. the positive side is the updates have been almost daily sent out to patch the issues.

Gameplay
If you know Dungeon Keeper then you will have an idea to play this game.
For those who dont what Dungeon Keeper is firstly I recommend buying that game as well as this game. Secondly This game is a Dungeon managment game where you are the EVIL UNDERLORD (Queue Thunder and Lightning) where you are basically wreaking the good guys" by building a dungeon that attracts creatures to your "humble" abode. Like DK you do have to pay them and keep them fed as well as train you creatures to destroy the damnable heros for your conquest.

there is of course some tidbits that makes the game like DK great like SLAPPING THE IMPS TO MAKE THEM WORK FASTER or "accidently" killing one or two or.....I think you get it

Sounds and Music
the music is fitting as well as the sounds you can feel the dread that you cause your enemys muhahahaha...erm...sorry
date:
as far as the dialog goes you can tell the voice acter has waaaaaay too much fun which is a plus  and there is some funny quips and you also can hear what some of your creatures say some things.

Story
the story is well basic as far as I can go with it but that because I am typing this up when I got to level/map 4 so I dont urge my self to spoil anything but if anything the goal and the story is entertaining and clear cut.

Graphics
I am strickly a gameplay kind of person I would say look at the snapshots and Vid to judge for yourself It looks good enough for me.

Recommend
I do recommend this game but keep in mind that there is some parts that still have issues and is being worked on as we speak and there is not enough games where you are clearly the bad guy and loving it.

and a summery of pros and cons to consider
Pros
Voice acting
Good Gameplay
Great nostalgia value (take that EA *shakeing fist*)
Is updating a great deal

Cons
There is some glitches that happen
there were some frame drops
some features are not complete

Keep in mind there is a huge number of updates that went through the passed couple of days so take it with a grain of salt"

reviewText: This is most certainly THE best attempt at following up on Dungeon Keeper 2 in an attempt to create the long sought after DK 3 which many of us had waited for.  You'll slip into a nostalgia coma as soon recognise every single component in this game from your previous DK experience.  They nailed it!  But this is also where the problem comes in.\n\nThe game is a graphically pleasing, humour-filled remake of DK and not so much a sequel. Sure enough there is a bloody good load of newly added components, such as the titan creatures and a leveling" scheme which allows you to unlock traps
date: rooms and the odd creature using points called "sins".   Heck
recommended: they even have the original voice-over from the old DK games! Nostalgia overload.\nThe campaign is "alright" and provides you with around 9 hours worth of gameplay - less if you are just one of those gamers who nail-it fast.  I completed the campaign a day after I bought the game and then
hoursPlayed: you are stuck with very few options.  The sandbox modes are pretty much blank maps with infinate gold that allows you to quickly dig out enough space and place all of your dungeon rooms and summon all of your creatures - provides you with around 30 minutes of entertainment.\nMultiplayer is an excrutiating experience.  For those of you who have been playing games outside of steam's DRm
voteText: you'll remember those horrible tech nightmares where you had to go and mess about with your port settings
helpfulPercent: enabling UPnP on your routers and so on - the days we all thought were long gone since steam (and other DRM's) provided a platform that negates this.  Well
votesHelpful: in the spirit of nostalgia you may well enough enjoy that experience in this game again.\n\nMultiplayer is stock standard
votesTotal: once you get it working.  Play against other opponents and squash them.  Whether it is you and a mate vs the AI (the developer's definition of Coop...if you can believe that) or whether it is two of you vs two other dungeoneers - all modes we should be fairly familiar with.\nThe actual coop which was hinted at during the kickstarter
votesFunny: though not reached
commentsCount: also seems to be not in the pipeline for the near future.  Now this does not mean it is off the table entirely
column16: though it doesn't look to be soon.\nThe expansion
column17: "Heart of Gold" (released two or three days prior to this review) adds about 4 - 6 hours worth of play in a campaign
column18: some dungeon visuall candy for multiplayer and the odd spell here and there.  It's not an expensive expansion and therefor the little content can be quantified.\nOverall
column19:
the game's base price vs what you get for it is not good at all.  This is the kind of game we should be looking for during steam specials.  You will barely get a weekend's worth of playing from both the game and its current expansion and multiplayer is unlikely to entertain you for very long if you get past the uneccesary setup hassles.
In summary:
They absolutely succeeded in providing a nostalgic experience in the spirit of Dungeon Keeper. No one can compete.
However

reviewText: The game has a very interesting premise, but it falls flat because of the interface.  The developers have obviously wasted quite a bit of time on fancy models and graphics but not enough on UI design.  The UI makes even simple tasks quite difficult to accomplish the worst offender being that they replace your mouse cursor with a fancy animated hand that you can never tell quite what is being pointed at without waiting for the cursor highlighting to catch up.\n\nThe scale on which things happen also tends to make things difficult.  The overall map is quite large relative to the individual unit and the player base is required to be somewhat large to support any decent number of units and the units themselves are quite tiny.  Zoom in to issue orders to units and you cant navigate the map as easily, zoom out to navigate and you cant issue orders as effectively; there is no zoom level where you can effectively do both.

reviewText:
It's clear that these Devs love Dungeon Keeper, and really do have talent. This game does have the chance to truly claim the title as the spiritual successor to DK2.

But as of the release, it's not there. There is still so much that is only placeholders, a bit of stability issues, difficulty is all over the place (AI in particular), and it really is one of the LEAST intuitive games I've ever played. Even mucking about in the sandbox and I've not even an idea how to find my minion cap. The free skirmish currently only has 3 maps, all 1v1 and horribly small even for that.

This game was NOT ready for release. And it won't be for some time. When it is, I'll update my review to say so.

reviewText:
This game has come a long way but it is NOT a finished product. For instance, I can't load any saved games. I save the game and it seems to happen successfully but when I go to load from a previous save it just isn't there. this makes the game completely unplayable for me. I am not going to start from the very beginning every time I want to play, having to redo the tutorial over and over again. Not happening. While it is a great game that shows a TON of promise it should have never been released in this state. It is beta material.

It feels like they are completely misrepresenting the state of the game by selling it in it's current state as a finished product.

***EDIT***

After a little more fiddling it appears that when Steam is in online mode the game is still saving games locally so after it saves the game and you try to load it it is bypassing the local game saves and only looking at the saves on Steam Cloud. After taking Steam offline I found the saved game I made while Steam was in online mode. Seems like a bug? A pretty big %$@ bug to have AFTER release you think?

So to those individuals having this issue you will just have to take Steam into offline mode to play for now until they fix the issue.

reviewText:
Honestly, I'm not very satisfied with this game. I'm about four missions in, and it is essentially the same game Dungeon Keeper was with a graphical overhaul. Feels almost like it's running the exact same engine with higher resolution textures.

It's been about 18 years since Dungeon Keeper came out, but War for the Overworld plays essentially the same as it's predecessor. Games have changed and improved quite a bit in that time, but WFTO is stuck in the past.

The Good:
Same quirky atmosphere you likely enjoyed with Dungeon Keeper.
Simple, casual gameplay. Nice voice acting. A pleasant way to spend a few hours.

The Bad:
AI is generally clunky and bad on both sides. Your minions are not very bright, but neither is the enemy.
Many maps are so full of caverns and holes that you can't really design a dungeon the way you want it to look. The map forces your hand in most cases. Combat is a complete mobfest, and usually involves dropping everthing and the kitchen sink onto your enemies heads, spamming heals and shooting some lightening. There is no strategy required.

The Verdict:
Did you like Dungeon Keeper? Do you want to play it again with unit reskins and higher resolution graphics? If so, then sure, grab this game. If you want a deep and strategic dungeon building game then you will have wait because this isn't it and nobody has made it yet.

reviewText: Diffculty for the levels are so easy its boring. Creatures just run to my core and die, or my creatures are 4-6 levels ahead of the empire/other underlords. There needs to be a difficulty mode implemented for players that like a challenge. Also the level designs are somewhat discouraging to futher me wanting to play more. Every single level just has water/lava/small corridors/impentrable rocks everywhere so I'm not allowed to make my dungeon how I'd prefer to make it. The empire traps are very weak, the crossbow you see on the 2nd/3rd level are very inaccurate. It lands a shot 10% of the time. I could go on but you get the just of how a veteran Dungeon Keeper 2 player forms his opinion of WftO as of its current state on patch 1.2. In comparison to this campaign levels/design to DK2, DK2 is better in most aspects, even the difficulty - DK2 had a very casual player difficulty campaign, but there were some maps atleast that even casual players had a time beating. Unlike yours truly.\n\nAnother side note is the Vein of Evil - The spells you get are so imbalanced, can destroy entire armies just by spamming certain spells in a corridor because there are no cooldowns and do too much aoe damage.

reviewText: Do you like Kickstarter projects? Are you willing to be patient and not get your reward for a while? If not, Dungeons 2 is a better game for you at the moment. If you are, I have good news. This game is perfectly playable. The tool tips are a little off, and there are a few bugs you'll encounter, but the game works, and is very fun! Setting up the perfect dungeon, working out a floor plan that works, planning trap setups, watching your army wreak havoc, turning your foes into your minions through torture, it really feels like you are an evil overlord! The best comparison I can make is if you Kickstart a tabletop RPG, and this is the pdf of the final project. You get it and have fun with it, and it only builds your enthusiasm for when you get your printed copy. Even if you don't want to support the game right now, keep it on your radar. I'm certain it will just keep getting better.

reviewText:
As of 1.0.14
4/6/2014
Going to wait for game to be polished a bit better. The game itself is good, but bugs, lack of proper tooltips, and omg memory leaks. I have 16g of ram and on lvl 4 of campain it ate 8g then crashed.

Building: Tutorial says 3x3 minimum for builds, but doesn't say if 3x4 is better or a waste of space. 6x6 adds another device so one would have to conclude 3x3 or 3x6 or it's wasted space. Rooms don't need walls so rip it all down except your chokepoint to enemy.

Minion AI: lol, have a full 6x9 slaughter pen and a empty 3x3 pen and minions are afraid of starving to death.
Workers don't multitask, they all tear down walls or they all convert blocks or they all mine gold (even if gold is capped..lol) or they all sit idle.
Scout beasts engage enemy instead of scouting.

Tool tips: Some are still displaying script descriptions. Most that are working have data stretched horizontaly so it goes 1/4 to 1/2 way across screen. Most info is irrelevant and needed info is no where to be found.

Hand and Camera: [del] key for camera tilt movement...really? that key should be to get rid of unwanted worker that was summoned over cap thats costing mana.
Screen edge movement is good, but hard to hit minimize button in left hand corner.
As with all rts type games, camera does not scroll out far enough. (Curse you Warcraft 3 for starting that crap.)

Enemy AI: lol, healers heal themselves or attack instead of healing the tank. Assasins chase a goblin accross map instead of staying with battle group. Dwarves think they are tanks. Tanks spin around and around till they are dead not knowing who to hit.

Traps: What traps? Death blosson is just a wall. Cannons are defense not a trap. It needs traps that do damage once to an unsuspecting mob.

Models: Other than the fact that they are all carbin copies (no unique faces, racial pigment or even hair color) The humanoids look good for the most part, but monsters look like a 2000 game (see Sacrifice by interplay). Succubus have wings BTW, do it right or call them S&M chicks. None of the models have a WOW that is cool feel except Shades.

Textures: Heh, didn't I already tear down this group of walls? Oh this one is fortified, see the grey smudge on top....really? Water looks like brown poluted water from a city sim game. Madel textures are minimal and not very detailed.

Concusion: Dungeon game? No it is a tower defense game that also lets you attack their tower after you get a zerg army together. So far this isn't even a diamond in the ruff, it is a turd with sugar sprinkled on it. Why everyone is so fixated with a 1997 game? Dungeon Keeper was good but expand on it. If you could combine Dungeons(Kalypso) with this game it would be good start. They both had a good thing, but to many want to play DK and DK2. Have it so you keep what you build and expand out into the world taking territory. Whats the point in building a dungeon to not have invaders?
At this time I can not recomend this game. Will try again in a month...maybe.

reviewText:
April 5th 2015
I am a fiend for God games/base builders still have and play both DK, Evil Genius, Startopia, etc.
I supported this game as soon as it released on steam.  I opened and ran in Alpha.  However now after the release I can't even get the game to run..... just sad.  I am encouraged by the patches hoping that one of them fixes whatever the problem is so I can play it.

April 9th 2015
I was encouraged when it started up for the first time for me yesterday and I got to play through the first 3 levels.  Graphics are ok.  Gameplay is good.  I like that you can pick up pieces of traps produced and set them on the sillouettes of traps that you have laid in order to help build them.  I like the idea of the sins as an experience tree in order to unlock new rooms and powers.  I was really pumped..... but then I came home from work today and tried to load the game and it did not load again.  I have tried 5 times and everytime it goes to not responding.  I have verified that my install is good through Steam so that isnt the problem.  I really want to give this game a chance and a place in my favorites if I could play it.  Just to prove that, I was about to give it a thumbs up thinking the problem was solved.  All the time I spent trying to load the game today had me go from 6 then increased to 7 hours of gameplay even though I didnt even really play.  Please keep patching!!!  I am very hopeful!

April 18th 2015
I was able to get the game to start up and I binged played through a bunch more scenarios. I really like the game when it is working. Got in about 10 hours more of gameplay. Afterwards thought I tried to start up the game 10 times in a row and it crashed everytime. If they keep patching I am hopeful for a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am a huge fan of the dungeon keeper series, this game being the spiritual successor of dungeon keeper II, I was more than happy to purchase the alpha early game access the instant I became aware of it.  I await updates to the alpha early access with bated breath.

Do not purchase the alpha for the early access unless you're a die hard fan.  Instead wait for the release so you shall not be disappointed with the development builds.  The horrendous mobile game that was released by Mythic/EA with the dungeon keeper title should be avoided and shunned at all costs for ruining the franchise.  Instead go buy and play dungeon keeper gold (1998,) and dungeon keeper II (1999.)  both of which are not on steam unfortunately, try gog.

reviewText: Game is full of bugs, unfinished, their entire thinking of what should Dungeon management  be is wrong. I am simply to afraid to continue playing it because I have a feeling it will dissapoint me too much I would have to delete it and never look back. reviewText:
I REALLY wish I could recommend this one, but I simply can't. It's unfinished, buggy, poorly optimized, and the mechanics are opaque at best.

The content, as it is, is water thin at the moment with a thirteen level campaign against a ♥♥♥♥ easy AI and three 1v1 AI skirmish maps. Patches were promised, but they have yet to manifest themselves.  The bugs are also still pretty bad. I am currently stuck on level nine because the game consistently crashes when I'm roughly halfway through with the mission.

Worst of all, the game lacks the sort of interesting interactions and special units that made Dungeon Keeper so intriguing. Building oddly shaped or larger than usual rooms bring no additional benefits. You'll never have a super cultist or unique monster appear in your dungeon. Furthermore, the inclusion of a so-called tech tree is haphazard at best. Since the tree doesn't really chain and basic rooms require sins to unlock, it doesn't enhance the game so much as slow down a dungeon's expansion.

There's a lot of potential here, but I feel like the game launched at least three months too soon. Save your money, people.

reviewText:
I'm very sad, about the fact that I'm having to provide a negative review on this product. As a hardcore fan of the Dungeon Keeper series, I wanted this game to succeed very, very badly. The sad thing is that, it does! It's just technically unplayable.

There are no bugs, or not to my experience at least. No glitches, weird errors, crashes, or anything of the sort. And the gameplay is very, very funny, and exciting!

(NOTE: Many players have reported a great number of bugs! I just personally haven't run into any, and made it to lvl 3 of the campaign without encountering any glitches and or bugs.)

However, as I approached the end of the third campaign level, in which you VS another underlord, with spells like you posess also, the game went total ape ♥♥♥♥. I haven't been able to fix it, and no solutions are to be found anywhere on the www at all.

The level went well, until I came into actual contact with my opposer. The AI controlled underlord, started casting all sorts of spells on my creatures as they pushed the edges of his base back, slowly but surely. The FPS dropped immediatly as the casting began, to 2 - 7 FPS.

Now before you all start questioning my specs, and wether or not my pc should be able to handle this title. I run some top of the notch hardware. Two GTX Titans overlocked in SLI , 64-bit, 32GB RAM, Intel Core I7-4930K CPU 3.40GHZ.

They have yet to invent a game that my system can't handle, so no excuses developers!

I am literally halted in my tracks.  And I can't play the game I payed for any further, until this matter is resolved. Therefor, I advice all potential buyers to WAIT, and not purchase this title, until a fix has been provided officially.

Once there is a fix, I'll consider providing a positive piece of feedback.

The devs have made several posts on the community hub, in which they state they've 'improved the FPS issues' however, I've had no confirmation of this what so ever, nor any positive feedback regarding this subject from any other buyers.

Good game, terribly optimized!

Fix this, so we can play this gem in the rough!
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game promised to be the 'Spritual successor to Dungeon Keeper'. What I got was a game that forced me to rush and I couldn't sit back and enjoy.

I wanted to love this game. Back in my youth I played the origional Dungeon Keeper to absolute death. What I loved about that was the humour and the ease of building a dungeon and that if you wanted you could sit back and stratergise and do well, or speed out and rush and hit the objectives hard and fast before your opponant knew what was happening.

WftO however seemed to rush me to constantly rush and attack and make rash choices about where to dump rooms or dig, or force me to build defenses with no proper set up. I found myself unable to plan leaving rooms exposed and routes to my dungeon core easy to exploit.

The humour is there, but it feels forced, thus making it not that funny at all.

In just 2 hours, I'd already gotten through 6 of the 13 levels without trying hard at all. At that pace, I'd not even have gotten 6 hours out of the main campaign. Even buying it on sale, £15 for 6 hours gameplay is pushing things.

The problem is, there isn't really anything massively wrong with the game. Its well made, the graphics are nicely designed, the interface is easy to pick up and use.... Theres just a large number of small problems that chip away at the enjoyment and feel of the game making it one I can't recomend, even to fans of the genre.

reviewText:
War For The Overworld is a real time strategy game, very similar to Dungeon Keeper, both from a gameplay and atmosphere point of view.

You view your dungeon from a top down perspective, drag-select tiles to order your imps to dig space for you to construct rooms, which attracts various types of monsters through a portal. Give them food and a place to sleep, train them to improve combat skills, and then send them out to kill the heroes. Some minions can research spells or construct traps. You can hold captured enemies in a prison, torture them to convert them to your cause, or let them die so their corpses can turn into undead minions at a graveyard.

There's a fun, dark sense of humour, especially thanks to the advisor, who is the same voice actor from Dungeon Keeper. As a fan of DK, it really does feel like everything I'd want to see from an unofficial sequel.

I wish I could end the review there with a positive recommendation. Unfortunately, my enjoyment of WFTO has been spoiled by terrible technical performance. I've suffered from two significant problems.

The first is a very frequent stutter"

hoursPlayed: especially when you're moving the camera around the map.\n\nThe second - and far more serious - problem

reviewText:
If you like DK1 and 2, you should definitely give this a go. It sticks extremely close to the formula.

Pros:

* Feels like other DK's
* Similar DK humour (Lol'd at Chunders)
* Overall just really good!

Cons:

* Subtitle text is too small and is pure white meaning it's hard to read on bright backgrounds
* All of the buildings have the word 'Prop' in them. e.g. Instead of 'Barracks' it's called 'Prop Barracks'...not sure why.
* When you look at buildings/creatures and what they're doing it's not very specific whereas in DK2 it was very specific about what was going on so you could micromanage very well.


EDIT: I've been playing it for a bit longer since my initial review.

The game is too buggy. Here are a list I've encountered so far (The good aspects of the game still stand, but it's also buggy).

- Frequently getting 'Insufficient mana' when trying to cast a spell even if my mana is full.
- Imps ignore the boundaries set by the flag to stop them possessing land
- I played a skirmish game and nothing happened. No units came at all.
- Several graphical glitches
- The sidebar buttons are wayyy too small to hit with a cursor. The whole UI is a bit finnicky, I'm not sure if it's just too small?
- Placeholder variables in the actual game content. This is unacceptable. Things like 'Identified : False' and 'Team:null' are very lazy placeholders which they need to remove asap. I also encountered one where a beast was going for food and it's status was something along the lines of 'Going to HUNGER_VAR at slaughterpen'...not cool.
- When you possess a creature, the movement feels janky and jerky.

I think more than anything, they need to seriously review their code. By the sounds of it, they're rushing it and introducing more bugs.

Still, If you like DK (not donkey kong) and don't mind a few annoyances, I'd recommend it.

reviewText: This game is pretty much a straight remake of Dungeon Keeper 2 with some names changed and without the handy map function.  That would not be a bad thing, only I have found it buggy and extremely slow.  It has never exited without crashing, room tiles vanish without a reason, sometimes can't pick up creatures from your prison, takes minutes to load on a computer that runs Skyrim with ease, etc.\n\nIt also badly needs a manual to understand many of the features, which is a shame because a lot of thought obviously went into some of them.  Some of the voice acting is pretty good too.  I feel bad saying this about something trying to carry the flag of a game I love, but I can't recommend it.  It suffers from being too like the original without enough added content or new features, and it seems to run worse than the original did on far older ones.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What to say about this one? well I can't really say I was too disappointed by this game because it is the true Dungeon Keeper successor and I was never able to play that game due to it being too old and too finicky with modern systems to get running but I really wasn’t impressed by anything in this game either. It has good intentions but it's really not all that interesting, even going along the campaign and unlocking new abilities, traps and room types the game never got more exciting than the 'oh yay new dungeon management game, im sure this will be good!' thrill at the start.

Here are categories on why I was barely able to enjoy the game:

Storyline: 3/10What storyline? It's so bland and forgettable I'm pretty sure it's there so the devs could say 'we made a storyline!'. I can sum it in afew sentences. Your evil and stuff, you get betrayed by alot of other evil people you have kill on the way to the top, once you kill all forces of good and become the most evil dungeon lord you get betrayed in a very obvious way you could have predicted way ahead of time and poof game done, yep… seat clenching. It is a shame because surely someone can think of a neat storyline for an evil dungeon lord coming from the bottom all the way to the top of the world? Even if it was taken non seriously like a joke, “They made fun of your really cool hat, knocked over your letter box and keep killing your zombie collection for fun, they must pay!” might have been better. Meh, not a big gripe for a game like this but it never really feels like I have any incentive to killing all these 'good' characters and ruining their world other then, your bad mkay? kill stuff cas the game gives you no other options, ugh. What did they look at me wrong? call my mum a bad name? Not put the toilet seat down?! Why do I hate them to the point of torturing them!? The game never explains that, if it even could, it's not very fulfilling at all and it just made me want to end the game as quick as possible.

Campaign: 4/10It took me barely 8 to 10 hours to get done, not alot of depth, not alot variety, a very linear experience from one click spot to the next, I don't know what more to say about this that wouldn’t repeat the storyline section, with no engaging storyline to follow the campaign felt pretty bland and meaningless. I was only doing it to get my monies worth out of the game about half way in and it just left me so unsatisfied at the end I ditched the game right after finishing it and never plan to come back to that waste of time and effort. If you’re looking for an amazing single player experience in this I’m sorry look somewhere else...

Graphics and Visuals: 3/10Oh boy is this a major gripe. This must have been made on an old Unity engine cas as far as advancing gaming graphics goes it looks terribad, and I really wish I was exaggerating. Great models and textures but not the right game engine to show them off in! Even the lighting in this is nothing special, there is no real visual evidence that your dungeon is as evil ,dark and monster filled underground hell as it is supposed to be, I was never really fully immersed by it and that's such a disappointment. Oh yea and don't even get me started on the joke of an anti-aliasing option... it's either have sharp visuals with jaggies for days or mega FXAA that blurs the whole game to such a degree you can barely make out the details of a single object or texture *shudders*. Just, no, if you appreciate graphics like me you will have a depressing time here, again all this is to blame for the crappy Unity engine they chose.

Performance: 2/10Performance, oh boy! You can imagine a game that's not open world with not much going on and poor visual fidelity will run great right? Well no, not at all, no hopes, again the Unity engine strikes to make this game run dreadfully on my gtx980 with 16gbs of RAM semi top of the range rig. On the last few missions my frame rate got down to a solid 12! I crap you not, 12!! If I was lucky I got 17 fps. With no optimization to be heard of this game will run like the alternative name for a donkey as soon as your dungeon gets to any decent size. I could have turned down the graphics maybe, but it already looked bad enough with no blurry AA on I didn't dare try, and on a gtx 980 why the heck should I have to?! Top of the line graphics cards aren't cheap for a reason right?

Variety: 7/10Moving off the biggest gripes, the variety is pretty good, a large range of different room types which also equal a different minion type for most of them, spells, traps, side powers you can call on to help you out abit and even little ease of life constructs. The enemy sends you a decent variety of enemies to annihilate and you even fight other underlords at afew points, this is all great, if it weren't for the insanely boring combat that you have to endure with to progress...

Combat: 3/10About all you can do is possession control a minion for some FPS interesting involvement but that gets boring quick due to a single minion never being able to make that much difference even while played by you. The only other thing you can do to help combat is the healing and rage spells and zapping enemies with lightning if they go on any of your territory and slip by, other than that it's just misc helpful spells to run the dungeon and spamming the attack banner around so your stupid minions actually move and attack everything else, nothing goes much deeper than that. Maybe I wasn’t being creative or was missing something? But I doubt it because I tried everything I was given, waiting for a crud ton of minions to spam then just blob charging them at the enemy was the only thing that seemed to work so I went with it for the whole campaign, not very engaging. =/


CONCLUSION: Total 4/10I guess after all that the only final conclusion can be... don't waste your time and effort on this, really just don't. This is quite frankly the most boring dungeon management game I’ve played so far, it does nothing new from Dungeon 1, Dungeon 2 and Impire, I can actually say that Dungeon 2 is more fun purely because of interesting mechanics and a playable dungeon lord that always gives you something to do! This game however will consistently show you how bland an unengaging, unsatisfying management game can be. Other than building 5x5 basic 'blocked' rooms and doing some spells and building traps I never really felt like I had any reason to be in this game 'helping'. A disappointing shame but it happens, bad engine and not enough thought and depth put in by the devs. Even the management in Overlord 2 was cooler lol, the minions in that game had personality and where so loveably evil and fun.

Buy this when it's majorly on sale if you really want or find something else because this really is a hit and miss for me and mind you I have played every dungeon management game I have found so far so hopefully everything I said holds enough water for you to believe me, because this review is in -your- interests.

Thanks for reading, game smart, game on.

reviewText: I purchased this game a few years ago because I was really excited about a new version of Dungeon Keeper. I have tried playing multiple times and every time I run into some game-halting bug. Each time I try playing, I ending up stopping to wait for the bugs to get fixed. When I first started the game was in early access so I decided to cut them some slack. But now it's the full version of the game and I still can't play because of these bugs that basically make gameplay impossible.\n\nI really want to like this game. It's a fun concept and the devs have obviously done a ton of work on it and made an almost-great product. But the focus seems to be entirely on adding content rather than making sure the existing content works. It doesn't matter how great your graphics are, how many levels you have, and how many different rooms and spells and monsters you've thrown into the mix. If people can't play because of bugs, your game is bad.

reviewText:
TL:DR at end.
Well, I'll start by saying that I love this game, it really is a modern dungeon keeper. I'll continue by pointing out some downfalls: compared to the first 2 there's not many improvements in my opinion; it seems to be made to be a lot easier too, hence 10 hours to complete campaign (with 5 crashes); It feels like it's still in beta, which i will now expand upon but first let me point out i have not read what the developers have to say about current state & patch roadmaps because I shouldn't have to, Someone releases a game and you expect it to be ready for release: This is not.
I'll be light on this subject because if you dont care about these things, you'll enjoy the game, I know i did.

First, too many towers crashes the game; that's right, a dungeon defense game and if you build too many defenses, it will crash. One mission in particular, campaign mission 9, you have to defend a bottleneck which is of course perfect for towers but no, build them and after 2 mins you'll be restarting.

Secondly, it's obviously not finished, mouse over a minion and it will tell you their current task which almost always is psuedocode, for example (and I'm paraphrasing here ) you will see current task do_GOLD_prop(dugeon.heart)  instead of 'get paid'  or get_raw_food_prop(pigfarm) instead of 'eat micropig'; further to this the interface doesn't work as it should, want to see your list of minions? it will often forget to turn the boundery of the list into scroll bars so you can only see the first 6 or 7 types of minion.
Thirdly it takes an insane amount of RAM, I'm not sure if there's a leak in there or whether it doesn't use GFX dedicated ram properly but 4.5Gb of RAM to run? Dont get me wrong, I have enough RAM but DAMN, that's more than any other game in my library (and i have a lot).

So yes, plays well if you dont build towers or use the ritual ro reveal the enemy dugeon (yup, that's a crash too!), nothing too immersion breaking on the interface apart from being able to only see half your force and taking 2 seconds to see what your minion is doing instead of 1/2 a second and if you dont have much RAM you may have performance issues, apart from that, a 9 hour sp experience(if you dont crash), only 3 skirmish maps, all very small & multiplayer/survival is still not working right now.

TL:DR
slapped a micropig, it squeeled and popped and made me smile, 12/10 now stop reading reviews if you cant be bothered to read.

reviewText: I can vouche this one.  Was a backer (even though the title wasn't given due to the fact that my pay method wasn't accepted for it).  In the last 2 days this game has been patched with steadfast determination.  I have followed this game for YEARS.  It is one of the very few games out there that promised and delivered after a ton of ups and down within the production.  The game in itself is made with the Unity engine.  The DK series was a favorite of mine from the beginning, and was a kick to the balls when EA bought it and did what they do best.  Round filed it.  These ppl saw a community who was begging for more from the DK title, and took it upon themselves to dev WftO, even though they had to cover their azzes to keep the game in the spirit of the DK genre while making it their own.  This group never promised anything it didn't deliver.  Not once in the promotion of the game did they make it look like it was anything but what it is.  I have faith in this product to be a quality piece.  I have played many games that were top titles that were released in WAY worse shape, and WAY more expensive.\n\nI give this game 10 thumbs up and played it for about 66 hrs.  It had some laggy issues with the AI pathing which seemes to have been patched out, and 2 bugs with completion which also has been fixed.  If you want a blast from the past with a new twist, this game is a definite buy.  If you are worried about the bugs, give it a day or 2 to let them sort out the release and then buy it.  This is a must for anyone that is a fan of the DK series, or the god" game genre.  I have been reporting and watching the WftO forums
date: and I must say that not once have they not replied quickly to any reports or comments.\n\nHop to see you soon Underlord!"

reviewText: Do you remember Dungeon Keeper 2? You did like it right? Well there's nothing else to say then, for the remaining people, continue reading.\nWar for the Overworld is a RTS game which puts you in the shoes of an Underlord: a mystical being which has the power of creating dungeons and using the forces of evil (minions and so...). The purpose of the game itself is to build your own dungeon, and that's where all the fun lies. Many Underlords prefer building traps, other train their creatures to death in order to slay enemies, others use a mixture of both. While doing so you also know how to use some magic that can help your cause. To build your dungeon you have workes to help you, just tell them where to dig, what to do and they will without fail. By creating space you can start build rooms that will attract creatures to your dungeon.\nPretty interesting right? Well, the campaign is well done but incosistent: some moments are far too easy and some other are hell itself. I haven't yet tried the multiplayer, but the game is actively developed and I think there will be many interesting suprises with time. A game worth its money.

reviewText:
This game, an obvious copycat of Dungeon Keeper (and that's not a bad thing), is very much like a disorienting disco where too many hallucinogens have throttled the experience from the mundane to the overwhelming. It's not that this game is bad. Actually, if they corrected a few mistakes, this game could be very cool. Unfortunately, the couple of problems that this game has makes for a disorienting and annoying experience.

First, the color palette is inappropriate to the genre, and, additionally, it is distracting to they eye. Let's face it, dungeons are dark places that are lit by torches. Fluorescent greens, oranges, and yellows do not belong in dungeons, except in the rare circumstance where magic is present. Most of the time, dungeons are like dungeons. That is, they are cold, dark, and earthy. Just looking at this game for too long can burn your retinas. I advise against that.

Second, the camera control is very limited. I want to be able to get a greater view of the happenings in my dungeon, dammit. Making me stay stay close in scope in relation to the goings on in my dungeon makes me dissatisfied. I'm the CEO of the dungeon, right? Shouldn't I be able to see the greater picture?

Like I said. I don't think this is a bad game, but it lacks insight into the basic wants of the RTS gamer.

feeling int the zone. Next level after defending for 30 mins I held strong. I then counter attacked and lost my army but they had nothing left so I built up another army. I built this army up for ages and it got massive.

reviewText:
This game, an obvious copycat of Dungeon Keeper (and that's not a bad thing), is very much like a disorienting disco where too many hallucinogens have throttled the experience from the mundane to the overwhelming. It's not that this game is bad. Actually, if they corrected a few mistakes, this game could be very cool. Unfortunately, the couple of problems that this game has makes for a disorienting and annoying experience.

First, the color palette is inappropriate to the genre, and, additionally, it is distracting to they eye. Let's face it, dungeons are dark places that are lit by torches. Fluorescent greens, oranges, and yellows do not belong in dungeons, except in the rare circumstance where magic is present. Most of the time, dungeons are like dungeons. That is, they are cold, dark, and earthy. Just looking at this game for too long can burn your retinas. I advise against that.

Second, the camera control is very limited. I want to be able to get a greater view of the happenings in my dungeon, dammit. Making me stay stay close in scope in relation to the goings on in my dungeon makes me dissatisfied. I'm the CEO of the dungeon, right? Shouldn't I be able to see the greater picture?

Like I said. I don't think this is a bad game, but it lacks insight into the basic wants of the RTS gamer.

reviewText: The game is laggy and glitchy.  The minimap is a pixelated mess.  Overall, not really all that fun and very time-consuming.  I wish I hadn't spent the money that I did on it.  The mouse is even an annoying hand.  I mean, do yourself a favor, and instead of playing through the levels on this where you really can't build your own dungeon (the campaign are all missions which tell you specifically what to do, and I can only assume the multiplayer would be even worse glitch-wise) and get something good like Command and Conquer if you're all about the overhead gameplay.  This leaves very little room for your own style of play, which is what really made it a negative for me.  I culd try to assume maybe it was my alienware that wasn't running to spec, but the glitches are numerous, it takes forever to load, the graphics leave something to be desired, etc.  It's just a pain in the ♥♥♥ to play, and when I go to attack with my minions and beasts, half of them don't pay attention to the rally flag, hich is another negative as you can only command your people to go to one place.  There is also no group selection or anything of the sort.  Either tell ALL of them to go HERE or leave them to their business.  This leaves no way to strategize about letting production continue and defend with certain minions, etc.  Overall, this is a piece of ♥♥♥♥ game in my opinion, and a waste of time if you're looking for something that allows for real RTS.

This game is possibly THE BEST Dungeon Keeper game to date. The game captures Dungeon Keeper in its best forms. You have all the things Dungeon Keeper had. Making the dungeon, imps, gold, the heroes, everything that you knew about Dungeon Keeper is in this game right here. This is an artfully crafted Dungeon Keeper game that brings the game back from the grave. If you LOVE Dungeon Keeper you will LOVE this game.

Pros: Dungeon keeper (Duh)

Cons:....T-theres water....Ok i havent played the game long but i already love it in the short time ive had it.

Dungeon Keeper was a game i played as a child, im 19 now and i am loving this game. I definatly, DEFINATLY reccomend this game be bought by every single person on this Earth...Or be scentanced to the pitch black dungeon.

reviewText:
Just finished the single player game. Difficult to give a thumbs up here, as much as I want to give one to the spiritual successor of some of my favourite games, which I loved so much that I actually bought WFTO once on Kickstarter and once in Steam.

In terms of mechanics it mostly works all right, except for that weird bug where prisoners keep dying as they are dropped into prison (just save and reload) and that thing where Revelation never ends so you can't use another ritual. Mostly all right. Performance and graphics wise it's decent. Just don't expect nifty extras like the special torture animations for different characters, here they are all the same.

But the single player campaign missions... so simplistic and skeletal compared to Dungeon Keeper 1 and 2 both. Whoever designed the missions have not benchmarked their work against the predecessors and told themselves they must do better; it is more like they have never tried the old ones. It is a real shame to see all the working mechanics but such poor missions. By the time the game ends you probably won't even have tried half the spells/traps/rituals/potions/ on offer and easily never use several room types and minion types, the mission are just that insipid and easy. Everything is kill everything".

Balance issues abound as well. It is simply too easy to convert enemies quickly
date: DK 1 and 2 had the same issue but not quite so strongly. This makes supposedy tough missions trivial - defeat the first enemy wave and you immediately have enough minions to steamroll all the objectives. This goes hand in hand with the bizarre abundance of infinite gold resource on so many single player missions - it makes the game trivially easy! I finished it all and never even tried ghouls
hoursPlayed:
or vampires.. because you don't need it when you have 50 monsters fighting a handful.

I have not tried the multiplayer. It is difficult to give it a try when the single player was always wonderful in DK1 and DK2 and so different here.

Overall the campaign felt painfully abbreviated vs DK1 or DK2 and the ending was emotionally a big letdown as well. You should NEVER have a situation in a game where the boss died in 10 seconds and his taunts then play one after another for half a minute! Seriously devs..

I guess it's worth buying if it's on 50% sale
voteText: or if they have some kind of free expansion with another 15 missions.\n\nREALLY hope this game becomes moddable so people can step in with proper single player mission designs and rebalance things like how easy torture conversion is. Don't need your voiceovers. Just good missions."

reviewText: This game is like the old dungeon keepers, but with only two forms of strategy. The only hope for the keeper is to attack or keep monsters around the heart by flagging the heart. Fortified walls can be broken through very easily (just by simply digging), and the AI constantly bum rushes the player. Also, most of the levels already have a pre-made dungeon for you. The game just throws you in and expects you to know what to do. Overall, this is a poor spiritual successor for the old dungeon keepers. Stay away from this game.

reviewText: Disappointing, I know this is an indie project but when you sell it as the successor to Dungeon Keeper you hope for a bit more. The graphics are serviceable but lack some of the edge and charm of the original. The balance is super patchy - some levels feel too easy some levels hard in maddening ways. One example being a later level where you can chew throw two foes quickly only to find the third has an infinitely spawning group of high level forces, workers and mana - even with half of their base conquered!\n\nIt feels like a competent update but the magic isn't there and the frustrations push it over to a no for me. Really I was looking for more than an update to the old game. Playing this after Keeper RL and having seen the trailers for Dungeon 2 also push me to think they really could have done more.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game had a lot of potential.
It's horribly put together and is riddled with issues; AI pathfinding is atrocious and your minions are nigh on impossible to control. This wouldn't be a problem if this was a relaxing romp through the joys of building a dungeon and repelling would be invaders or seeking out objections in your own time.

The crucial problem, and the deal breaker for me, is the excessive focus on speed and micro management that seems to underpin every aspect of this game. It's like somebody took Dungeon Keeper soul and flayed bits off of it and crammed it into a Starcraft tournament.

I kept wanting to like this game but I cannot in good conscious recommend it. I am not enjoying it.
The developers seem a good bunch and are dedicated to getting the game running as best it can but owing to the inherent game design issues I have with this game it wouldn't be enough.

I may come back in a few months when it's actually finished.

reviewText:
May/june 2015:
Purchased this without looking too much into reviews, after playing it for a few levels, i had huge FPS drops, until it became unplayable. I managed to finish the level, and move on to next, after a while it's on again.

It's not my computer, the game is just not optimized. Been looking forward to this game since DK2 so it's fair to say I am disapoint.

1/10 got tricked into buying into beta testing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's only a beta so far...but I like it!

Unleash your evil side after a bad day at work, school or whatever and build the dungeon of your nefarious dreams to lure those goody-two-shoes into so they can die.  Build in a way that pleases you most; weather that be beasts and violent minions, undead and necromancers...to raise more undead, or somewhere inbetween the two.

Unleash your frustrations, unleash your inner evil...no matter how small it may be!  :P

reviewText: The devs have admitted this game was released while it was still in early access condition and as of right now the game is very much unplayable due to this. To start with the UI is very slow, like 2-3 seconds slow. Leaving for some very choppy gameplay, ive reported this on the official forum and after a month there has still been no fix, ive since asked the devs again if anything will be done about this with no response, im guessing they have given up with this bug. During my play through of the game ive encountered around 40 to 60 crashes and as of right now I am still not able to get past level 7 due to game breaking bugs. I will update my review when they have fixed all of the game breaking bugs.
